anna_coexistence_hint.text: It doesn't want to possess. It just doesn't want to be alone. Konrad could have been its friend. But Konrad resisted.

anna_fear_narration.text: I understand it suddenly. The creature did not call me out of hunger. Out of hope. Six hundred years of loneliness, and now someone is here who might listen — and it is terrified that I will run away.

narration_anna_realization.text: I am not the victim. I am the threat. Since I touched my name in the book, since I learned the chant - the creature knows what I intend. And it is desperately trying to stop me.

anna_6.text: Please, Elise. Hurry. I can hear its voice growing louder. Soon I won't hear anything else.

elise_voss_anchor_drill.text: Voss' Warnung aus der Kirche hämmert noch in meinem Kopf: Hand auf Stein, den Namen eines geliebten Menschen nennen. Ich habe das seit Mitternacht wie ein Gebet geübt - nicht um brav zu gehorchen, sondern um in dieser Nacht nicht an den falschen Stimmen zu zerbrechen.

elise_anna_promise.text: I will end it, Anna. For you, for Konrad, for everyone. I promise.

narration_determination.text: As Anna vanishes among the trees, I feel something new. Not fear - determination. The creature is afraid of me. Then I have a chance.

journal_reality.title: Reality Is Breaking
journal_reality.content: Day 6: Reality is growing thin. The forest grows, the village distorts, colors are no longer right. Anna says the entity dreams of me - it's afraid. The Feeding is tomorrow night. I must act before then.

narration_spiral_payoff.text: Die Spiralen an den Hauswänden treffen mich diesmal nicht unvorbereitet. Dieselben Zeichen habe ich in der Kirche gesehen - älter als das Dorf, älter als jede Lüge, die man mir erzählt hat.

narration_tree_payoff.text: Seit dem Fund am Wächterbaum weiß ich: Das hier ist kein Aberglaube. Der Boden selbst reagiert auf das Wesen. Und heute reagiert ganz Graubach mit.

anna_konrad_trust_payoff.text: Du hast Konrad vertraut, obwohl alle dich gewarnt haben. Das hat es gespürt. Für einen Moment hat es geglaubt, es könnte durch dich etwas anderes sein als nur Hunger.

anna_konrad_distrust_payoff.text: Du hast Abstand zu Konrad gehalten. Verständlich. Aber es hat das als Zurückweisung verstanden - und drückt jetzt umso härter in seine Träume. Wenn er heute Nacht fällt, fällt er nicht zufällig, sondern weil Einsamkeit immer den leisesten Spalt sucht.

anna_konrad_tested_payoff.text: Du hast Konrad geprüft, nicht blind geglaubt. Das war grausam - aber es hat ihn geweckt. Manchmal hält Misstrauen jemanden länger bei sich als Mitleid, weil es einen zwingt, sich jeden Tag neu für sich selbst zu entscheiden.

narration_2.text: In the mirror I see myself. But my reflection blinks half a second later than I do.

narration_1.text: Graubach's church is no less menacing in daylight. The bell tower juts into the grey sky like an admonishing finger.

elise_approach.text: Grandmother's journal mentions a chamber beneath the church. Built upon something older, deeper. The key in my pocket feels warm, as if it wanted to go home.

narration_2.text: I push open the heavy oak door. It yields with a groan that sounds like a sigh.

narration_3.text: Inside, it is cold. Colder than outside. The stained glass windows cast pale patterns on the stone floor, but the colors look wrong, shifted.

elise_cold.text: The cold comes from below. Through the stone floor, through the soles of my shoes, into my bones. The same cold as in grandmother's cellar. The cold of something breathing beneath the earth.

narration_4.text: I search the chancel. Beneath a faded tapestry, I find a stone slab with carved symbols. Spirals, intertwined.

elise_spirals_recognize.text: These spirals. On the gravestones, on Konrad's hand, in grandmother's journal. Now here, beneath the altar. They all point in the same direction: downward.

narration_5.text: When I touch the spirals, I feel a vibration beneath my fingertips. Not mechanical — organic. Like a heartbeat, deep beneath the stone.

elise_heartbeat_react.text: It's alive. Right beneath me, under stone and earth. I feel it not only in my fingertips, but in the place where my name is tied to it. As if the thing below has been waiting for this exact touch.

voss_appears.text: A voice behind me. 'I wouldn't touch that if I were you.'

voss_1.text: Fräulein Brandt. I saw you coming. This church... it is not what it seems.

elise_voss_1.text: I know that, Pastor Voss. I found grandmother's journal. I know about the chamber. About what sleeps beneath it.

voss_smells_herbs.text: You've been to see Hilde. I can smell her herbs. Good. Then you already know there is more here than prayers and incense.

elise_hilde_knowledge.text: Hilde told me about the chant. And the sign of the earth. If you know where the thinnest point in the chamber is, you can save me time, Father.

voss_hilde_react.text: The old pagan knows more than the Church would ever admit. Yes. I know the thinnest point. I will show you where you must stand.

voss_3.text: Thirty years I have been pastor here. Thirty years I have stood on this ground, preaching of one God, while something else lurks beneath my feet.

elise_voss_thirty.text: Thirty years. The same number as the ritual. As grandmother's struggle. Is that coincidence?

voss_3b.text: Nothing in Graubach is coincidence. Thirty years is the cycle. And it is nearing its end.

choices: Confront him directly: What do you know about the feeding?
Ask cautiously: What can you tell me about this church's history?
Lie: I'm just looking for a quiet place to pray.

voss_confronted_1.text: He flinches as though I've struck him. Then he sags, bracing himself against a pew.

voss_confronted_2.text: So you know. Georg has spoken. Good. Good that someone says it aloud.

elise_confront_press.text: 1893. Friedrich Meier. You were there, weren't you?

voss_confronted_3.text: I saw it in 1893. I was twenty-five. They took Friedrich Meier down there. I heard his screams — and then... then they stopped. And the singing began.

narration_voss_tears.text: His hands are trembling. In his eyes stand tears that are thirty years old.

voss_confronted_4.text: I became a pastor to fight evil. But this thing... it is not the devil, Fräulein Brandt. I would prefer the devil. At least I understand him.

elise_confront_comfort.text: My grandmother trusted you. She wrote that you were the only one who believed her.

voss_confront_react.text: Margarethe... yes. She was the only one who understood. We met every month. For thirty years. And now she is dead, and I am alone.

elise_confront_ally.text: You are not alone. I am here. And I intend to finish what she started.

voss_careful_1.text: The history? This church has stood since 1346. But the cellar... the cellar is older. Much older. The peasants built the church over something that was already there.

elise_careful_ask.text: Something that was already there? The spirals on the stone slab - they're not Christian. They're pre-Christian. Celtic perhaps, or older.

voss_careful_2.text: There are records. Old chronicles. The first pastor wrote: 'We have set the house of God upon the maw of the demon, that His light may banish the darkness.'

voss_careful_4.text: It didn't work. The light banishes nothing. It simply goes on sleeping, no matter what we build over it.

elise_careful_react.text: Because it is not a demon. It is older than your religion, Pastor Voss. Older than all religions. My grandmother understood that.

voss_lied_1.text: Pray. Yes. I pray every day too. But I'm no longer sure anyone is listening.

voss_lied_2.text: He studies me. In his eyes lies a recognition, as though he knows I am lying.

voss_lied_3.text: Your grandmother was often here too. She didn't pray. She... searched. Just like you now, Fräulein Brandt. Just like you.

elise_lied_caught.text: He knows I'm lying. There's no point. In this village full of lies, I am the worst liar.

voss_converge_2.text: If you truly want to know what lies beneath this church, come at midnight. Come alone. If Otto's men see us, neither of us will leave that chamber.

elise_midnight_why.text: Why at night? Why not now?

voss_converge_2b.text: Because Otto has the church watched during the day. The mayor has eyes everywhere. At night, the eyes sleep.

voss_converge_4.text: But bring the key. Your key. Without it, the inner door is sealed.

elise_key_confirm.text: I will be there. With the key.

voss_converge_5.text: One more thing. When you are down there... the singing will grow louder. It will try to get inside your head. Think of something real. Of someone you love. That helps.

elise_voss_thanks.text: Thank you, Pastor Voss. For the warning. And for standing by my grandmother.

journal_church.title: The Church
journal_church.content: Found spirals beneath the altar — they vibrate. Pastor Voss knows more than he lets on. He wants to show me the entrance to the chamber at midnight. The church was built over something older.

narration_leave_church.text: I leave the church. Outside, the sun is shining, but it feels thin, as though filtered through too much water.

elise_leave_thought.text: Tonight. In a few hours I will go down, to where the singing comes from. To where my name is written in a book older than I am. The thought frightens me. But the fear has grown smaller. Behind it, something else is growing: determination.

choices: Margarethes Namen als Anker wählen
Annas Namen als Anker wählen
Georgs Namen als Anker wählen

anchor_name_margarethe.text: Wenn es in meinem Kopf drückt, nehme ich Margarethes Namen. Sie hat diesen Kampf angefangen - ich halte ihn bis zum Ende.

anchor_name_anna.text: Ich nehme Annas Namen. Er erinnert mich daran, wofür ich unten standhalten muss: dass niemand mehr geopfert wird.

anchor_name_georg.text: Ich nehme Georgs Namen. Er hält die Linie oben, ich halte sie unten - derselbe Takt, zwei Orte.

anchor_name_commit_converge.text: Gut. Nicht erst unten entscheiden. Ein Name, klar gewählt, ist stärker als zehn improvisierte Gebete.

voss_anchor_margarethe_response.text: Margarethe also. Gut. Dann haben Sie unten nicht nur einen Namen, sondern eine Linie: von ihr zu Ihnen. Halten Sie diese Linie im Atem, nicht im Kopf.

voss_anchor_anna_response.text: Anna ist klug gewählt. Kinder benennen Dinge klarer als wir Erwachsenen. Wenn das Singen Sie verwirrt, nehmen Sie ihren Blick als Maßstab: Was schützt Leben, was frisst es?

voss_anchor_georg_response.text: Georg gibt Halt, ja. Dann koppeln Sie unten Stimme an Stimme: sein Rhythmus oben, Ihrer unten. Keine heroischen Sprünge - nur Takt halten.

elise_heartbeat_hint.text: And in that recognition there is no hostility. Only... expectation. Like a dog that hears someone at the door and lifts its head.

narration_1.text: Day four. In the village square, I run into Konrad by chance — or what disguises itself as chance. He sits on the edge of the fountain, reading.

narration_inner.text: Grandmother's words stand before my eyes: 'He is the vessel.' The man who sits there so peacefully reading carries something ancient within him. And he may not even know it.

georg_warned_about_konrad.text: Georg warned me. 'Be careful with the teacher,' he said. His eyes were more serious than I've seen in anyone. Konrad's smile conceals something.

georg_warned_2.text: I will be friendly. But on my guard. Every question I ask, every answer he gives — I will listen closely. Not just to the words. To what lies between the words.

konrad_1.text: Fräulein Brandt! What a pleasant surprise. Please, sit down. I have fresh coffee — real coffee, not that substitute.

elise_greet.text: Good day, Herr Müller. My grandmother often told me about you.

konrad_react_greet.text: Did she? That pleases me. Margarethe was a special woman.

konrad_remembers_door.text: Ah, it's nice to see you in daylight. Our nighttime encounter was somewhat... unfortunate. You must think me strange.

elise_door_react.text: Yes, it surprised me. What brought you to Grandmother's house at night?

konrad_door_excuse_defensive.text: Sie haben mich letzte Nacht schon durch die geschlossene Tür ausgefragt. Ich verstehe Ihre Vorsicht. Wirklich. Ich wollte trotzdem nur mein Beileid aussprechen.

konrad_door_excuse.text: I wanted to offer my condolences. Old habit — Margarethe and I often chatted in the evenings.

narration_door.text: He is lying. Or telling a half-truth. Grandmother did not write about evening chats in her diary.

narration_suspicious.text: I know what grandmother wrote about him. The vessel. I must be careful.

narration_charmed.text: Something about him draws me in. He is different from the other villagers — educated, open, curious.

konrad_2.text: I've been thinking about your grandmother. Margarethe was a remarkable woman. Did you know she taught me to read?

elise_react_reading.text: I did not know that. She never talked much about Graubach. At least not... not in recent years.

konrad_4.text: When I was a child, she came every Wednesday. She read to me, showed me a world beyond these mountains. Without her, I would never have become a teacher.

elise_personal.text: That sounds wonderful. I wish I had visited her more often.

konrad_6.text: She always had a secret, your grandmother. Something she never shared. Have you discovered it?

narration_test_moment.text: He asks so directly. His eyes seek mine — calm, attentive. Too attentive? Or merely curious?

choices: Trust him and tell him about the tradition
Distrust: Answer evasively
Test him: Tell him about the spirals and observe his reaction

elise_trust_1.text: Herr Müller... Konrad. I know about the tradition. About the book beneath the church. About the feeding every thirty years.

konrad_trust_silence.text: He says nothing. His face barely changes — but his hands around the coffee cup turn white with tension.

konrad_trust_2.text: I know. I think I have always known. Not the details, but... the feeling. That something is wrong in this village. That I am wrong.

choices: Nach den Erinnerungslücken fragen
Nach den Spiralen und den Händen fragen

elise_missing_time_ask.text: Wenn dir Stunden fehlen: Gibt es einen Auslöser? Glocken? Orte? Irgendetwas, das kurz davor immer gleich ist?

konrad_missing_time_answer.text: Ja. Erst wird alles zu still, als hätte jemand Watte in die Welt gestopft. Dann höre ich eine einzelne Glocke, obwohl niemand läutet. Wenn ich wieder da bin, stehe ich meistens näher an der Kirche als vorher.

elise_spiral_signs_ask.text: Und die Spiralen? Tauchen sie auf, bevor du wegkippst oder erst danach?

konrad_spiral_signs_answer.text: Danach. Immer an den Händen, als hätte jemand meine Finger geführt. Wenn ich sie wegwasche, brennen die Linien noch stundenlang, als lägen sie unter der Haut.

elise_trust_ask.text: What does it feel like? Can you... can you sense it?

konrad_trust_describe.text: Imagine you are standing in a dark room. You know you are not alone. Something breathes behind you. But when you turn around, there is only... yourself.

konrad_trust_dreams.text: Sometimes I dream things that are not my dreams. I see... deeper. Older. As though I were merely a shell.

konrad_coexistence_hint.text: But there are moments... when I stop fighting... then it's almost peaceful. As if one were sitting beside someone, not trapped inside someone.

elise_coexistence_react.text: Not fighting, but coexisting? The thought is more disturbing than anything else. And yet — something about it rings true.

choices: Ein Notfall-Stoppwort festlegen ('Mittwoch'), um ihn im Hier und Jetzt zu halten
Kein weiteres Experiment - nur weitersprechen

konrad_interrupt_word_set.text: Wenn du wieder wegrutschst, sage ich nur ein Wort: 'Mittwoch'. Der Tag, an dem Großmutter dir vorgelesen hat. Nicht Magie - Erinnerung.

konrad_interrupt_word_response.text: Mittwoch. Gut. Wenn ich nicht mehr weiß, wer spricht, halte ich mich daran fest.

konrad_interrupt_word_skip.text: Ich lasse den Impuls los, noch eine Technik auszuprobieren. Gerade jetzt braucht er keine neue Regel, sondern eine klare, ruhige Stimme.

elise_trust_vessel.text: Konrad... Grandmother called you 'the vessel' in her diary.

konrad_trust_vessel_react.text: He closes his eyes. A tremor runs through his body — brief, violent, as though an electric shock had hit him.

konrad_trust_4.text: The vessel. Yes. That... that explains a few things. You know, Fräulein Brandt, sometimes I wake at night and my hands are drawing spirals. Without my wanting them to.

narration_trust_horror.text: A shiver runs down my spine. He is describing possession from the inside — and it does not sound like a monster. It sounds like a prisoner.

elise_distrust_1.text: Nothing special. Old letters, recipes. Memories of an old woman.

narration_lie.text: The lie comes more easily than expected. But my voice sounds too high, too even.

konrad_distrust_2.text: Only memories? No... records? No notes about the village?

elise_distrust_push.text: Why would she have notes about the village?

konrad_distrust_shift.text: His smile changes. The warmth fades. For a moment something seems to slide behind his pupils. Something old.

konrad_distrust_3.text: Of course. Only memories. Graubach is a perfectly normal village, after all.

elise_distrust_shiver.text: The way he emphasizes 'normal' makes me shiver. He knows I am lying. And I know that he knows.

narration_distrust_horror.text: His voice suddenly sounds different. Deeper. Older. As though not he were speaking, but something THROUGH him. Then he blinks, and the old Konrad is back.

konrad_distrust_5.text: Forgive me. I am somewhat... out of sorts today. Sleep was not good.

elise_test_1.text: The church is fascinating. Those spirals on the walls — have you noticed them? I know similar patterns from my folklore studies.

konrad_test_react.text: His hand twitches. Involuntarily he grabs his wrist — right where I saw the faint spiral patterns on his skin at our last meeting.

konrad_test_hide.text: Spirals? I... no, I do not pay attention to church decoration. Pastor Voss's domain, not mine.

elise_test_push.text: Strange. You just covered your wrist. Do you have such patterns too?

konrad_test_3.text: Spirals? No, I... I do not know any spirals.

narration_test_lie.text: He is lying. And he knows that I know it. The air between us grows heavy. I say nothing more — sometimes silence is more revealing than questions.

konrad_walk.text: Come. Let me show you something. The forest behind the school — there is a place there that your grandmother loved.

elise_forest_hesitate.text: Alone with him in the forest. With the man grandmother called 'the vessel'. Any sensible person would refuse.

narration_forest_why.text: But I am not here to be sensible. I am here to understand.

narration_forest_1.text: The forest path leads deeper than expected. The trees stand so close together here that barely any light gets through. Konrad walks ahead, sure-footed, as though he knows every root.

konrad_forest_reply.text: Sometimes. When school is over. The forest is a good place to think.

narration_forest_walk.text: His steps are sure, almost automatic. As though his body knows the way even when his mind is elsewhere.

narration_forest_2.text: He stops at a clearing. In its center stands a single, ancient tree. Its trunk is twisted, grown in a spiral.

konrad_tree_1.text: The villagers call it the Guardian Tree. It has stood here for centuries. Your grandmother came here often.

elise_tree_1.text: Spirally grown... like the patterns in the church. Like the marks on your wrist.

konrad_tree_3.text: Do you feel it? The ground here... it breathes.

elise_tree_feel.text: Yes. Beneath my feet. A pulsing — like a heartbeat.

narration_tree.text: He's right. Beneath my feet, there is a faint pulsing. Like a heartbeat, deep in the earth. The same rhythm as beneath the altar.

konrad_humming.text: Konrad stands motionless before the tree. His lips move, barely visible. He is humming — a melody I know. The melody from the depths.

elise_humming_react.text: The song. You are humming the song — the singing from the depths!

konrad_humming_react.text: He flinches as though I had struck him. His eyes widen — confusion, fear. Real fear.

konrad_humming_2.text: I... what? I was not... I did not know I was...

narration_humming_pity.text: He does not know it. He hums the creature's song without realizing. Like a sleepwalker who does not know where his feet are taking him.

elise_humming_comfort.text: It is all right. It is not your fault, Konrad.

konrad_humming_3.text: Nothing here is my fault. And at the same time everything is my fault. Or that which is inside me.

narration_pity_moment.text: For the first time I do not see him as a threat. But as a victim. A man, trapped between himself and something older than the mountains.

konrad_possession_1.text: I observe him more closely. There — his gaze turns glassy. For three, four seconds there is no one behind his eyes. Then he returns, confused, as though he had been dreaming.

konrad_possession_2.text: How... how long was I just...? What did I say?

konrad_possession_3.text: The creature sleeps and dreams through him. In those moments Konrad is not Konrad — he is a window through which something ancient peers. And the gaps are growing longer. Whole hours, he said, that he cannot account for.

journal_konrad.title: Konrad and the Guardian Tree
journal_konrad.content: Konrad showed me the Guardian Tree in the forest — grown in a spiral. The ground there pulses like beneath the altar. Konrad behaved strangely — his hand twitches at the mention of spirals, his eyes change. Grandmother's journal confirmed it: He is the vessel.

narration_return.text: We walk back to the village in silence. Konrad whistles softly to himself. The melody sounds familiar — it is the singing from the depths.

elise_return_thought.text: Can one free a vessel without breaking it? Or has Konrad Müller long since ceased to be Konrad Müller?

narration_2.text: His smile is warm, inviting. But grandmother's words echo: 'His eyes were not his own.'

konrad_door_narration.text: He mentions our encounter casually, as if it were the most normal thing in the world. But why was he at grandmother's house at night?

konrad_trusted.text: I tell him everything. About the tradition, the book, the feeding. He listens without interrupting.

konrad_trusted_3.text: I know. I think I've always known. Not the details, but... the feeling. That something is wrong in this village. That something is wrong with me.

konrad_trusted_5.text: Sometimes I dream things that are not my dreams. I see... deeper. Older. As though I were merely a shell.

konrad_trusted_6.text: He says it so calmly, so matter-of-factly. As though he were talking about the weather.

konrad_distrusted.text: 'Nothing special,' I say. 'Old letters, recipes, memories.' The lie tastes bitter.

konrad_distrusted_3.text: He smiles, but the smile doesn't reach his eyes. For a moment — just a moment — something seems to slide behind his pupils. Something ancient.

konrad_distrusted_4.text: Of course. Only memories. After all, Graubach is a perfectly normal village.

konrad_tested.text: I mention the spirals in the church in passing. 'Strange patterns,' I say. 'Do you know them?'

konrad_tested_2.text: His hand twitches. Involuntarily, he grasps his wrist — right where I noticed the faint spiral patterns on his skin the other day.

konrad_tested_4.text: Spirals? No, I... I don't know any spirals.

konrad_tested_5.text: He's lying. And he knows that I know it. The air between us grows heavy.

narration_1.text: Day three. The morning sun falls through the dusty curtains, but it brings no warmth. I barely slept.

elise_wakes.text: At some point during the night, the singing grew louder. It formed words that I almost understood in my half-sleep. Now, in the morning light, they have vanished again - like fragments of dreams you cannot hold on to.

heard_singing_memory.text: Das Singen aus der Nacht hängt noch in meinen Ohren. Nicht mehr nur Angst - ein Muster. Drei tiefe Töne, zwei hohe, immer wieder. Als ich später Großmutters Journal lese, erkenne ich dieselbe Struktur im "Gesang der Alten".

fled_morning.text: The memory of last night burns. The forest that shifted. The paths that all led back. Graubach holds me fast. So I must find another way.

stayed_morning.text: I chose to stay. The key lies on the nightstand, the spiral facing up. In the morning light, it looks harmless. Almost.

narration_kitchen.text: In the kitchen I find grandmother's teacup. It sits beside the stove, half empty. Dried herbs on the rim. Mugwort and yarrow - the same tea that Hilde gave me.

elise_cup.text: I hold the cup in both hands. It is cold. But for a moment I can feel grandmother's hands that held this cup. Every morning. For thirty years.

choices: Einen Tropfen probieren
Die Küche gründlich absuchen

taste_cup.text: Der Tee ist bitter, fast metallisch. Beifuß, Schafgarbe, ein Hauch Eisenkraut. Dieselbe Mischung, die Hilde mir gegen den Nebel gegeben hat. Großmutter hat sich jeden Morgen damit geschützt.

search_kitchen_hint.text: Ich öffne Schubladen und Dosen, bis ich zwischen alten Rezeptkarten einen Zettel finde: 'Frische Bündel kühl halten - hinter der losen Kellerwand'. Kein Kochhinweis. Ein Versteckhinweis.

elise_morning_resolve.text: I put the cup back. Today I search for grandmother's records. Thirty years of research must be somewhere in this house.

narration_2.text: Grandmother's house holds answers. She spent thirty years working on an alternative ritual — her notes must be somewhere in here.

narration_cellar_hint_payoff.text: Der Zettel aus der Küche lässt mir keine Ruhe: 'hinter der losen Kellerwand'. Wenn sie etwas vor anderen verstecken wollte, dann dort.

choices: Search the study
Investigate the cellar
Thoroughly search her bedroom

search_study.text: The study is a chaos of books and papers. Grandmother was obsessed — dozens of books on folklore, occultism, pre-Christian rituals of the Black Forest.

elise_study_1.text: I recognize some of these books from my studies. Grimm's Mythology, Mannhardt's Forest and Field Cults. But others are unfamiliar - handwritten copies, pages in languages I cannot read.

search_study_2.text: Between the pages of a well-thumbed book on Germanic binding rituals, I find loose sheets. Grandmother's handwriting, tight and hurried.

find_notes_study.text: 'The seal must be renewed, not with blood, but with will. Three components: the sign of the earth, the chant of the ancients, and an anchor — someone who knows the entity but does not fear it.'

elise_study_react.text: An anchor. That word again. Konrad used it. Hilde too. And now grandmother. Am I this anchor?

search_cellar.text: The cellar smells of damp earth and something sweeter — herbs, perhaps. Dried bundles of plants hang on the wall, carefully labeled.

elise_cellar_1.text: The stairs creak beneath my feet. It is cold down here, but a different cold than outside. This one comes from below, from the earth itself. As if something beneath it were breathing.

search_cellar_3.text: Behind a loose stone in the wall, I find a tin box. Inside: a leather-bound notebook, a small pouch of herbs, and a folded note.

search_cellar_4.text: 'For Elise, when the time comes. You will understand. — M.' Grandmother's initials. The notebook is her journal.

elise_cellar_react.text: She hid it for me. Not in the obvious study, not in the bedroom. Down here, where the earth is cold and no one searches. As if she knew that others would also be looking for it.

search_bedroom.text: Grandmother's bedroom looks the same as the day she died. The bed neatly made, as though she had known she wouldn't return.

elise_bedroom_1.text: Her dressing gown still hangs on the hook. I press my face into it. Lavender and herbs. Her scent. For a moment I am six years old again and she is holding me in her arms.

search_bedroom_2.text: Beneath the loose floorboard beside the bed — where she used to hide sweets for me — lies a package wrapped in waxed cloth.

search_bedroom_3.text: An old notebook, filled with writing. On the first page: 'Records of the Entity Beneath Graubach. Begun 1893, continued to the present day.'

elise_bedroom_react.text: She used the hiding place that only I knew. The place where she used to hide sweets for me. One last message from grandmother to her grandchild.

journal_entry_found.title: Grandmother's Journal
journal_entry_found.content: Found grandmother's records. She documented 30 years of research on the entity beneath the church and an alternative binding ritual. Three components needed: the sign of the earth, the chant of the ancients, an anchor.

read_journal_1.text: I leaf through the journal. The early entries are sober, almost scientific. But as the years pass, the handwriting grows more restless.

read_journal_2.text: '1903: The spiral appears everywhere. In the bark of the trees, in the pattern of the frost, in my dreams. It knows that I am searching.'

elise_journal_react_1.text: The spiral. On the gravestones, on Konrad's hand, in Anna's drawings. Everywhere the same symbol. It is not decoration - it is a signature.

read_journal_3.text: '1915: Hilde taught me an ancient chant. It dates from before the Romans. When I hum it, the air grows heavy and the singing from the depths falls silent for hours.'

elise_journal_react_2.text: A chant that silences the creature? That is one of the three components. Hilde still knows it - she must teach it to me.

read_journal_5.text: '1921: Konrad's eyes. I saw it. For a moment, as the sun hung low, his eyes were not his own. The entity has found a vessel.'

elise_journal_react_3.text: Konrad. She knew as early as 1921. For two years he stood at my door and smiled, and behind that smile lives something that is not him. And yesterday I spoke with him as if everything were normal.

read_journal_6.text: '1923: I found the name. In the book in the chamber. Elise Margarethe Brandt. Written in an ink that pulses. My granddaughter. Who is studying in Berlin and suspects nothing of all this.'

elise_journal_react_4.text: 1923. My name was in that book before I was born. The creature knew me before I existed. It was waiting for ME.

choices: Erst ruhiger werden, dann Großmutters Kurs übernehmen
Trotz Angst weitermachen und alles kritisch gegenprüfen

stance_grounded_trust.text: Ich zwinge meinen Atem in einen Rhythmus und entscheide mich: Ich gehe Großmutters Weg weiter. Mit klarem Kopf.

stance_forced_verify.text: Ich dränge die Panik beiseite und lese weiter. Wenn ich überleben will, muss ich alles verstehen - und jede Annahme testen.

read_journal_7.text: '1923, Addendum: I will not allow my granddaughter to become a sacrifice. From today I work on another way. It will take thirty years. But I have thirty years.'

elise_journal_react_6.text: She did it for me. Not out of duty or tradition. Because she loved me. A grandmother who fought against an ancient being for thirty years so that her grandchild could live.

narration_midmorning.text: I close the journal. My hands are trembling. Grandmother knew about Konrad. She knew everything.

elise_plan_1.text: Three components. The sign of the earth - perhaps in the chamber beneath the church. The chant of the ancients - Hilde knows it. And an anchor.

elise_plan_2.text: I am the anchor. My name in the book is the connection. Grandmother didn't try to cut that thread - she taught me to hold it on my own terms. Not as a sacrifice, but as a bridge.

elise_plan_3.text: Can this work? Or am I reading hope into notes written by a woman who was running out of time and refused to admit it?

narration_plan_trust.text: Ich entscheide mich, Großmutters Spur zu folgen. Nicht blind - aber mit Vertrauen in dreißig Jahre Arbeit. Wenn ich jetzt zögere, war all ihr Opfer nur Aufschub.

narration_plan_pragmatic.text: Ich halte mich an den Plan, aber ich prüfe jeden Schritt wie eine Feldstudie. Kein Aberglaube, keine Panik - nur Entscheidungen, die ich begründen kann.

choices: Go to the church — search for the sign
Seek out Hilde — ask about the chant

narration_to_church.text: The church. That's where the chamber lies, where the rituals are performed. If there are clues to the sign of the earth anywhere, it's there.

narration_to_hilde.text: Hilde was grandmother's ally. She knows the chant. Perhaps she knows more about the other components too. The church can wait.

choices: Die Kräutermischung notieren und später mit Hildes Rezept abgleichen
Den bitteren Nachgeschmack als Warnsignal im Körper verankern

taste_cup_note_commit.text: Ich kritzle die Mischung auf die Rückseite von Großmutters Einkaufsliste. Kein sentimentales Andenken - ein Arbeitsprotokoll. Wenn Hilde dieselben Kräuter nennt, weiß ich, dass hier Methode hinter jedem Morgen steckte.

taste_cup_body_commit.text: Ich lasse den bitteren Zug nicht wegatmen. Wenn mein Kopf später kippt, suche ich genau diesen Geschmack als Gegengewicht: Beifuß, Schafgarbe, Eisenkraut - hier, jetzt, Körper vor Panik.

choices: Den Versteckhinweis direkt am Kellerzugang markieren
Den Zettel einstecken und niemandem davon erzählen

search_kitchen_mark_commit.text: Ich ritze mit dem Brotmesser ein kleines X in die Türzarge zum Keller. Später im Stress suche ich dann nicht, ich finde.

search_kitchen_conceal_commit.text: Der Zettel verschwindet in meiner Jackentasche. Falls Otto oder Konrad hier auftauchen, sollen sie gar nicht erst wissen, wonach sie suchen müssen.

stance_grounded_trust_payoff.text: Ich unterstreiche im Journal drei Sätze und schreibe nur ein Wort daneben: "tragen". Nicht alles beweisen - das Tragfähige zuerst umsetzen.

stance_forced_verify_payoff.text: Ich markiere jede Behauptung mit Randkürzeln: belegt, indirekt, offen. Wenn ich sterbe, soll wenigstens klar sein, worauf mein Plan gebaut war - und worauf nicht.

narration_plan.text: What else did she write? Three components for the seal. Hilde knows the chant. The sign of the earth — perhaps in the church? And the anchor...

elise_journal_react_5.text: My hands tremble so badly that I can barely hold the journal. I set it down. Breathe. One. Two. Three. Then I pick it up again.

narration_1.text: Day five. Midnight. The village sleeps — or pretends to. I creep through the empty lanes toward the church.

narration_2.text: Georg's key sits heavy in my pocket. Hilde's amulet rests against my chest. Grandmother's journal is in my bag.

elise_inner_ready.text: My hands tremble. But I keep walking. Grandmother worked towards this moment for thirty years. I will not let it pass.

voss_night_1.text: You came. Good. We have little time. Otto's men are patrolling — he has noticed that something is changing in the village.

voss_distrusts.text: But first... you lied to me in the church. About what you know. What you're looking for. I saw it in your eyes.

elise_voss_lied.text: I didn't know if I could trust you, Father. Can you forgive me?

voss_forgives_lie.text: Forgive? I am the last person who should condemn lies. I stayed silent for thirty years. That is worse than any lie.

elise_voss_greet.text: Thank you for being here, Father. I would not have wanted to do this alone.

voss_night_2.text: Voss leads me through a side door into the sacristy. There, behind a heavy curtain, lies a stone staircase leading downward.

narration_voss_leads.text: Voss leads me through a side door into the sacristy. There, behind a heavy curtain, lies a stone staircase leading downward.

narration_alone.text: The church door is locked. But Georg's key — it fits here too. The old iron turns heavily in the lock.

elise_alone_thought.text: Alone. No Voss, no Georg. Just me and whatever waits beneath the church. Grandmother did it alone for thirty years. I can manage one night.

narration_alone_2.text: Alone in the dark church. My candle casts trembling shadows. Behind the altar I find the staircase leading down.

narration_basement_1.text: The air changes at once. Warmer, damper, sweeter. The singing is no longer faint here — it fills the room, vibrates in my bones.

elise_descent_react.text: Nausea rises in me. Dizziness. The amulet on my chest grows warm - as though it were working against the pressure weighing on my thoughts.

narration_basement_2.text: The walls are covered with spirals. Carved, painted, branded. Layer upon layer, centuries piled atop one another. Some look like writing I cannot read.

voss_descent_1.text: Herr im Himmel, steh uns bei...

voss_descent_2.text: Nicht gegen DAS hier. Aber es hilft mir. Es erinnert mich daran, wer ich bin.

elise_voss_understand.text: I understand him. Down here, where the walls breathe and the ground pulses, one needs something to anchor oneself. For Voss it is his faith. For me... Grandmother's words.

narration_basement_3.text: On a stone pedestal in the center of the room lies a book. It is not old — it is beyond old. The leather is from no animal I know.

elise_book_first.text: My hands tremble as I touch it. The leather feels like... skin. Warm skin. It responds to my touch - a gentle pulsing beneath my fingertips.

narration_basement_4.text: I open it. Page after page of names. Hundreds of names, in different handwritings, written across centuries. Some have a date behind them. Some have a cross.

elise_crosses.text: The crosses. One every thirty years. The sacrificed. I count them and my stomach turns. So many. So many people who descended into this hole and never came back up.

narration_basement_5.text: The crosses. I count them. One every thirty years, going back until... the oldest entries are no longer writing, just symbols.

elise_grandmother_notes.text: Her notes. Small, neat letters: 'Friedrich Meier, 1893. Last sacrifice.' And further on: 'Konrad M. - not entered as sacrifice. Marked differently. Vessel?' Grandmother studied this book. For years.

narration_find_name.text: And there, on the last written page: 'Elise Brandt'. In a handwriting that does not look human. The letters are too even, too perfect.

elise_panic_1.text: My name. In a script no human can write. And the ink... the ink PULSES. It lives. It breathes beneath my fingers.

elise_panic_2.text: No. No, that cannot be. It must be a mistake. Someone wrote it in - Otto, Konrad, someone. But the script is not human. No human hand writes like this.

narration_name_1.text: I touch my name on the page. The ink is warm. It pulses beneath my fingers.

elise_panic_3.text: Grandmother knew. She summoned me BECAUSE my name stands in the book. Did she sacrifice me or save me? Or both?

narration_name_2.text: And then the singing stops. Complete, absolute silence. Silence that weighs heavier than any sound.

narration_silence.text: In the silence I feel it. Not hear, not see — feel. An attention, vast as an ocean, directed at me. It is awake. It knows I am here.

elise_awareness.text: It regards me. Not with eyes - with something older. I stand naked before a consciousness that saw mountains when they were not yet mountains.

narration_before_choice.text: The book lies open before me. My name stares back at me. What do I do now?

zugfrau_1.text: I page back. Dozens of pages, hundreds of names. And then — an old entry: 'Mathilde, 1863'. Beside it a drawing. My breath catches.

zugfrau_2.text: The drawing shows a woman with empty eye sockets. The blind woman from the train. She was no stranger — she was the last to survive the ritual. She waited sixty years.

elise_deliberate_1.text: If I erase the name - will I be free? Or will it only anger the creature? Grandmother wrote that the name always comes back.

elise_deliberate_2.text: If I take the book, I have proof. Control. But Otto will notice. And the creature... it will know something is missing.

elise_deliberate_3.text: Or I leave it here. Perhaps I do not need the book. Perhaps I need the CONNECTION that my name represents.

choices: Try to scratch out the name
Take the book
Back away — leave the book alone

erase_attempt.text: I scrape my fingernail across my name. The ink does not yield. I spit on the page, rub — nothing. As grandmother wrote: the name always comes back.

elise_erase_frustrate.text: As Grandmother wrote: the name always comes back. As though it were not ON the page, but IN it. Part of the book itself.

erase_3.text: The ground trembles. Dust trickles from the ceiling. The singing resumes — louder, angrier, like a swarm of hornets rising from the deep.

take_book.text: I close the book and take it. It is heavier than it looks, and warm, almost hot. As I lift it from the pedestal, the room shudders.

take_3.text: A sound — not singing, not a scream. A sigh. So vast, so deep that the stone walls vibrate. It has noticed that something is missing.

elise_take_react.text: The book presses against my chest like a heartbeat that is not my own. But I hold it tight. It belongs to me - or I belong to it.

leave_book.text: I step back. My instinct tells me: the book is not meant for human hands. It belongs below, in the dark, where it was placed.

elise_leave_reason.text: I do not need the book. I have something better: I now know that my name is a connection. And a connection can be used - without possessing it.

leave_2.text: The singing resumes gently. Almost satisfied. As if I had made the right decision — or the one it wanted.

book_converge.text: I must get out of here. Now. The walls seem to be closing in, the spirals spinning in my peripheral vision.

narration_escape.text: I stumble up the stairs, through the church, into the open air. The night air hits me like a blow. Cold. Clear. Real.

otto_encounter.text: In front of the church stands a figure in the moonlight. Broad-shouldered, motionless. Mayor Reinhardt.

otto_1.text: Fräulein Brandt. Out late. And with something that does not belong to you.

elise_otto_react.text: Herr Reinhardt. How long have you been standing here?

otto_2.text: Lange genug. Ich habe Sie beobachtet, seit Sie Hildes Hütte verlassen haben. Genau wie Ihre Großmutter - immer da, wo sie nicht sein sollte.

otto_3.text: Give me the book. And go home. Forget what you have seen. That is not a request.

elise_otto_defiant.text: My name stands in this book, Herr Reinhardt. In a script no human wrote. I believe I have a right to it.

otto_react_name.text: Rights? There are no rights here, Fräulein. There is only tradition. And tradition says: every thirty years it is fed. That has worked. For centuries.

choices: Give back the book
Refuse and run

give_book.text: My hands tremble as I hand him the book. Otto takes it with a care that contradicts his threat. He holds it like a baby.

give_book_3.text: Sensible. Just like your grandmother. She was sensible too — in the end. Go home, Fräulein Brandt. And stay there.

elise_give_whisper.text: In the end. What does that mean? Was Grandmother sensible - or did Otto silence her? The thought makes me shiver.

defy_otto.text: I press the book against my chest and run. Through the lanes, across the square, toward grandmother's house. Otto calls after me, but he does not pursue.

defy_narration.text: I press the book against my chest and run. Through the alleys, across the square, towards Grandmother's house. Otto calls after me, but he does not give chase.

defy_3.text: His last words echo through the night: 'That was a mistake, Fräulein Brandt. A grave mistake.'

defy_4.text: His call echoes through the night. But I am faster than an old man. And the darkness shields me - for the first time.

narration_home_1.text: Back in grandmother's house. I bolt the door, shove a chair against it. My hands are still trembling.

elise_home_process.text: I saw my name. In a script no human wrote. On a page that knows no error. And now I know for certain: I am no bystander. I am part of the story.

journal_book.title: The Book of Names
journal_book.content: In the chamber beneath the church lies an ancient book containing hundreds of names. Some bear a cross — the sacrificed, every 30 years. My name is the last entry, in inhuman script. The ink pulses. The entity knew I would come.

narration_end_1.text: I cannot sleep. The singing is louder than ever. It seeps through the walls, through the floor, through my closed eyelids.

elise_end_cover.text: I press my hands over my ears. It does not help. The singing does not come from outside. It comes from WITHIN. Since I touched my name, it is part of me.

narration_end_2.text: And in the pauses between the tones I hear words. Not German, not Latin, no language that should exist. But I understand them all the same.

narration_end_3.text: It says my name. Over and over and over. Elise. Elise. Elise.

narration_home_2.text: I have seen my name. In a script no human wrote. On a page that knows no error.

narration_1.text: Hilde's cottage sits at the edge of the forest, half hidden among ancient oaks. It smells of sage, chamomile, and something I cannot name — earthier, older.

narration_2.text: She opens the door before I knock. As if she had been expecting me.

hilde_1.text: There you are at last. Margarethe said you would come. Sit down. The tea is ready.

elise_arrive.text: You were expecting me? How did you know I would come today?

hilde_expected.text: Thirty years teach you to read the signs. You met Konrad, visited the church, read the journal. The next step was always to come to me.

narration_3.text: Inside the cottage, bundles of herbs, roots, and small pouches hang everywhere. On the walls are symbols I recognize from my folklore studies: protective runes, older than any church.

elise_runes.text: Those runes on your walls - I recognise them. Germanic, but with Celtic elements. We studied them in the third semester.

hilde_impressed_2.text: You have sharp eyes. Most people only see scribbles. Your grandmother recognised them immediately too.

elise_grandmother_question.text: Hilde... how was Grandmother in her last years? Was she happy here? Was she afraid?

hilde_personal.text: Hilde pauses. Her hands close tighter around the teacup.

hilde_personal_2.text: She was... resolute. Not happy, no. But not unhappy either. She had a purpose, and that gave her strength. In the last months, however...

hilde_personal_4.text: In the last months she grew quieter. She knew time was running short. And she was afraid - not for herself. For you.

elise_react_personal.text: For me. For thirty years she thought of me. Of the girl whose name stands in the book, even before she was born.

hilde_tea.text: Hilde pours me tea. The liquid is dark green, nearly black, and smells of earth and honey.

elise_tea_skeptic.text: What is in the tea? Forgive the question, but after everything I have experienced here...

hilde_tea_laugh.text: Ha! Suspicious. Good. Valerian, lemon balm, St. John's wort and a little thyme. No poison, no magic. Just herbs for the nerves.

elise_tea_drink.text: I drink. The tea is bitter but warming. Something truly loosens in my chest - a tension I have been carrying for days.

hilde_teaches_intro.text: Your grandmother and I worked together for thirty years. She was the clever one, I the patient one. Together we figured out nearly everything.

hilde_teaches_intro_2.text: There are three things you must know, child. Three components of the seal. I will teach you all of them — just as I taught Margarethe.

hilde_chant_1.text: The chant. Yes. The ancient peoples who lived here before the Celts knew sounds that could calm the entity. Not defeat it — calm it. Sing it back to sleep.

elise_chant_question.text: From my studies I know of sonic rituals among the Germanic peoples. But those were ceremonial. Do you mean the tones themselves have an... effect?

hilde_chant_confirm.text: Not the tones alone. The resonance. Listen.

hilde_chant_2.text: Hilde begins to hum softly. The melody is simple, almost a lullaby. But it feels different — the air grows heavier, warmer.

hilde_chant_3.text: And then — for a brief moment — the distant singing from the depths falls silent. Complete stillness. As if the earth were holding its breath.

elise_chant_amazed.text: It stopped. The singing - it is silent!

hilde_chant_4.text: Do you hear? Silence. The chant works. But I am old. My voice will no longer suffice for the full ritual. You must learn it.

elise_chant_try.text: I can try. But I am no singer, Hilde.

hilde_chant_teach.text: It is not about beauty. It is about intent. Sing with me.

narration_chant_try.text: I try to hum along with the melody. My voice is uncertain, trembling. But after a few bars I find the rhythm - and something responds.

narration_chant_response.text: Deep beneath us, barely perceptible, something shifts. The singing from the depths falters - only for a moment, but it falters. It heard me.

elise_chant_fear.text: It reacted. It heard ME. Hilde, it knows I am here!

hilde_chant_calm.text: It knew that already, child. Your name stands in its book. But now it knows you can SING. That is important.

choices: Practice the chant — I must master it
Later — I need more information first

practice_chant_success.text: I practice the melody over and over until it imprints itself into my bones. Hilde corrects me patiently — a tone lower here, a breath longer there. After an hour, it sounds... right.

skip_chant_practice.text: My head is spinning. The chant, the sign, the anchor — too much at once. I need to understand what all this means before I memorize it.

skip_chant_2.text: Don't wait too long, child. The chant needs practice. Without it, the seal is just an empty promise.

transition_to_sign.text: Hilde waits until the silence has settled. The singing from the depths resumes, timidly at first. Then she speaks again, calmer now.

hilde_sign_1.text: The sign of the earth is not a mark that one draws. It is a place. Where the entity comes closest to the surface.

elise_sign_question.text: The chamber beneath the church. Where the ground pulses.

hilde_sign_2.text: In the chamber beneath the church there is a point where the stone is thinner. There you feel the heartbeat most clearly. That is the sign — not made by human hands.

hilde_sign_3.text: Your grandmother found it. You must stand exactly there when you begin the chant. Otherwise the effect dissipates.

elise_sign_react.text: Standing directly above the creature and singing. That sounds like... knocking on a door and hoping that what lurks behind it does not open.

hilde_sign_honest.text: That is roughly what it is. The chant is the knocking. And yes - it could open.

transition_to_anchor.text: Hilde stands and walks to the window. Outside, the trees sway in the wind, as if listening.

hilde_anchor_1.text: The anchor. That is the hardest part. Someone must serve as a link between our world and the entity. Someone who knows it but does not fear it.

elise_anchor_question.text: What happens to the anchor? Does one survive it?

hilde_anchor_hesitate.text: Hilde hesitates. For the first time in this conversation, she avoids my gaze.

hilde_anchor_2.text: Margarethe wanted to do it herself. But she grew too old, too frail. As the anchor one must be strong - in spirit, not in body.

elise_anchor_press.text: Hilde. You did not answer my question. Does one survive it?

hilde_anchor_truth.text: Margarethe was not certain. No one has ever tried it. She died before she could find the answer.

narration_anchor_weight.text: Not certain. That means it could kill me. Or worse - it could change me. The way it changed Konrad.

choices: And if I die? What happens to the entity then?
Grandmother wanted to be the anchor. Why didn't she do it?

hilde_death_answer.text: If the anchor dies, the connection tears. The seal breaks. The entity awakens — confused, angry, hungry. That's why the anchor must be strong. And that's why it must be someone young enough.

hilde_death_answer_2.text: So I don't just have to survive — I have to survive a LONG time. Thirty years. Like grandmother.

hilde_margarethe_answer.text: She wanted to. Until the very end. But her body gave out. The anchor needs strength — not physical, mental. And Margarethe's mind was weary. Thirty years awake, thirty years vigilant.

hilde_margarethe_answer_2.text: She waited for you. Not because you are stronger. Because you are fresh. Because you still have the strength she had lost.

hilde_anchor_5.text: Elise... Margarethe believed that you could be the anchor. Your name in the book — it is not a curse. It is a connection. You are already close to the entity.

elise_anchor_horror.text: That means the creature KNOWS me? It knows who I am?

hilde_anchor_knows.text: It knows your name. It wrote it itself - in a script no human should read. Yes, child. It knows you.

narration_anchor_existential.text: A shiver runs down my spine. Something beneath the earth, older than humanity, knows my name. Wrote it before I was born. What AM I to this being?

anchor_callback_death.text: Die Rechnung ist brutal klar: Als Anker muss ich nicht nur mutig sein, sondern über Jahre stabil bleiben. Ein einziger Zusammenbruch kann alles zerreißen.

anchor_callback_legacy.text: Großmutter hat den Weg vorbereitet, bis ihre Kraft endete. Wenn ich weitergehe, trage ich ihr Werk - aber auch ihr Risiko.

hilde_warning_1.text: But listen to me carefully, child. There is someone you must not trust.

hilde_warning_surprised.text: You are quick. Yes - Otto. He is the keeper of the old tradition. He will do anything to enforce the feeding. And he has helpers.

hilde_warning_5.text: If he finds out what you intend — if he realizes you are continuing Margarethe's work — he will act. Swiftly and without conscience.

elise_warning_react.text: He could not stop my grandmother. He will not stop me either.

hilde_warning_smile.text: You are more like her than you think.

hilde_letter_1.text: Hilde... the letter. Grandmother's letter. How could it reach me in Berlin if she had already been dead for days when I arrived?

hilde_letter_2.text: Ah. That was Margarethe's last spell. She wrote it months ago and bound it with a time-binder — an old ritual that only delivers the letter when the recipient is ready.

hilde_letter_3.text: Not when she dies, but when I am ready? That means the letter... waited for me?

hilde_letter_4.text: Exactly. It waited for the right moment. The moment you were strong enough to come to Graubach.

hilde_creature_dual_1.text: And one more thing, child. About the creature. The elders invented the feeding — not the creature. They interpreted its loneliness as hunger and answered with blood.

hilde_creature_dual_2.text: Perhaps that was wrong. Perhaps a conversation would have sufficed.

hilde_creature_dual_3.text: Hilde pauses. In the silence I hear the distant singing — quieter than usual, almost questioning.

hilde_creature_dual_4.text: But who talks to what sleeps beneath the earth?

hilde_margarethe_death_1.text: In the end, Margarethe did it. She went down one last time, the night before her death. Not to fight. To talk.

hilde_margarethe_death_2.text: She came back. Lay down in her bed, smiled, and closed her eyes. She died in her sleep, child. Peacefully. It was a farewell, not a sacrifice.

hilde_margarethe_death_3.text: But Otto implied that her death wasn't natural...

hilde_margarethe_death_4.text: Otto lies. That's what Otto does. He wants to frighten you into accepting his feeding. Don't believe a word that man says about Margarethe.

hilde_margarethe_1.text: Georg says Grandmother failed. That her ritual did not work. But you sound as if you know something different.

hilde_margarethe_2.text: Georg believes she failed. Margarethe wanted it that way. She only told him half — to protect him.

hilde_margarethe_3.text: If Otto knew the ritual was complete, he would have long since... eliminated Georg.

hilde_margarethe_4.text: Hilde lowers her voice. The shadows in the cottage seem to grow thicker.

hilde_margarethe_5.text: The complete knowledge lies here. With me. And now with you.

hilde_gift_1.text: Hilde reaches into her apron and presses a small pouch into my hand. Inside are dried herbs and a round stone amulet with a spiral carved into it.

hilde_gift_2.text: Carry this with you. It does not protect against the entity — nothing does. But it protects against its dreams. You will be able to think more clearly.

elise_gift_react.text: Thank you, Hilde. For everything. For standing by Grandmother's side for thirty years.

hilde_gift_personal.text: Margarethe was my dearest friend. The only one who never thought me mad. And now you are here, and I am no longer alone with it.

narration_gift_moment.text: Her eyes glisten. For thirty years she carried this secret, together with Grandmother. And now the burden rests upon my shoulders.

journal_hilde.title: Hilde's Teachings
journal_hilde.content: Hilde taught me all three components of the binding ritual: 1) The ancient chant — older than any known language, it calms the entity. 2) The sign of the earth — a place in the chamber beneath the church where the stone is thinnest. 3) The anchor — a person with a connection to the entity. Grandmother believed I could be the anchor. Hilde warned me about the mayor.

narration_evening.text: As I leave Hilde's cottage, dusk is falling. The forest is closer than this morning. I am certain of it.

narration_evening_2.text: On the way back I hear footsteps behind me. Heavy, deliberate. I turn around — no one there. But among the trees hangs a cloying scent, like wilted flowers.

elise_stalked.text: My heart pounds. Among the trees hangs a sweet smell, like wilted flowers. The footsteps resume - closer this time.

narration_stalked_run.text: I run. The last metres to the road I sprint. Only in the lamplight before Grandmother's house do I stop, gasping for breath.

narration_stalked_who.text: Who was that? Otto? One of his helpers? Or something else entirely? The amulet in my pocket feels warm - as though it were working.

hilde_3.text: Your grandmother and I worked together for thirty years. She was the clever one, I the patient one. Together we figured out almost everything.

hilde_4.text: Almost. One piece is still missing. That is why you are here, child.

hilde_anchor_3.text: Margarethe wanted to do it herself. But she grew too old, too frail. As the anchor, one must be strong — in spirit, not in body.

hilde_warning_3.text: Otto Reinhardt. The mayor. He is the keeper of the old tradition. He will do anything to ensure the feeding takes place. And he has helpers.

narration_chant_hint.text: The faltering doesn't sound like defense. It sounds like surprise. As if someone had received an answer for the first time after a very, very long time.

narration_morning_1.text: The morning brings no relief. The fog has not lifted — it has only grown brighter, like a dirty sheet draped over the village.

narration_morning_2.text: At the village fountain I wash my face. The water is ice-cold. In the murky mirror of the surface I see my pale face. And for a moment — just a moment — I see a second face beside mine.

narration_morning_3.text: I flinch back. Nothing. Just my reflection.

elise_morning_1.text: My hands are still trembling from the water. Or from the night. I am not sure.

narration_morning_4.text: The people of Graubach show themselves by day. Women hang laundry. An old man chops wood. Children — few — walk to school with bowed heads.

narration_morning_5.text: No one speaks. No one greets me. Some look at me — brief, furtive glances, immediately averted. As though the sight of me makes them uneasy.

elise_morning_plan.text: I have to talk to the people. Someone in this village knows what happened to Grandmother. And someone will tell me the truth — whether they want to or not.

choices: Go to the church
Visit the herbalist at the edge of the village
Go to the schoolhouse — look for last night's visitor

church_1.text: The church of Graubach is old. Older than most of the houses in the village. The tower leans slightly to one side, as if something below were pulling at it.

church_2.text: The graveyard beside the church is overgrown. Headstones stand crooked; some have toppled over. On several I make out the same symbol: a spiral.

elise_church_spirals.text: The spirals on the headstones... I know this symbol from my studies. Pre-Christian. Celtic perhaps, or even older. But so concentrated in one place — that is unusual.

church_3.text: The church door is locked. But through a window I see candlelight inside.

voss_1.text: The side door opens. A man steps out — thin as a line, with sunken cheeks and eyes that have seen too much.

voss_2.text: You are not permitted to be here.

elise_church_intro.text: I am Elise Brandt. Margarethe's granddaughter. And I am looking for answers.

voss_3.text: His voice is hoarse, as though he had been praying for hours. Or screaming.

voss_4.text: You are Margarethe's granddaughter, are you not? Elise Brandt. I am Pastor Voss.

elise_church_how.text: How do you know my name? I have not yet introduced myself.

voss_4b.text: Everyone in Graubach knew your grandmother. And everyone knew you would come.

voss_6.text: Leave. Leave Graubach. Today. Take nothing with you, do not look back. Just go.

elise_church_defiant.text: My grandmother called me here. I will not leave until I know why she had to die.

voss_7.text: He grabs my arm. His grip is surprisingly firm for such an emaciated man.

voss_8.text: Your grandmother tried to stop it. She failed. And now you are here, exactly as they wanted. Leave while you still can.

choices: Who are 'they'? What do they want from me?
I am not going anywhere until I know the truth.

voss_q1.text: The village. The elders. The mayor. And... the Other. That which has no voice, but speaks through others.

voss_q2.text: I am a man of God, Fräulein Brandt. But what lies beneath this church... God has no words for that.

voss_d1.text: Voss looks at me for a long time. Then he releases my arm. His shoulders slump.

voss_d2.text: Just like Margarethe. The same eyes. The same stubbornness. She did not listen to me either.

voss_converge.text: Before I can ask more questions, a young girl appears in the side doorway. Blonde hair, pale skin, a gaze that looks right through me.

anna_2.text: She stops short. Her eyes widen. For a moment there is something in her gaze — clarity, horror, recognition.

anna_4.text: It's you. You are the one it draws. I see the spiral around you.

anna_4b.text: The singing. It sings your name. Over and over and over.

elise_follow_anna.text: Wait — what does she mean? What sings my name?

voss_blocks.text: Stay away from my daughter. She is ill. She does not know what she is saying.

anna_6.text: Voss pushes his daughter gently but firmly back into the house. Before the door closes, I see Anna's hand. She is drawing spirals in the air with her finger.

elise_anna_monologue.text: Ill? No. The girl saw me — truly saw me. She perceived something around me that I myself cannot see. What is the spiral? And why does it sing my name?

journal_voss.title: Pastor Voss and Anna
journal_voss.content: Pastor Voss warned me to flee. He knows of something beneath the church. His daughter Anna seems 'touched' — she saw a spiral around me. What does that mean?

hilde_1.text: At the edge of the village, where the last houses give way to the forest, stands a small cottage. Herbs hang from the door, and the garden is astonishingly green despite November.

hilde_2.text: The door opens before I knock.

hilde_3.text: I have been expecting you, child. Come in. The tea is ready.

elise_hilde_arrive.text: How did you know I was coming?

hilde_3b.text: Your grandmother told me about you. Often. You have her eyes, you know that?

hilde_4.text: Hilde Falkenberg. The herbalist of Graubach. Grandmother told me about her — a wise woman who knows the old ways. The ways before Christianity.

hilde_5.text: Her house smells of dried herbs, of honey and earth. Everywhere there are jars with strange contents. On the walls hang symbols — runes, spirals, and some I do not recognize.

elise_hilde_personal.text: Hilde... how was my grandmother in her last years? Was she happy here?

hilde_5b.text: Happy? No, child. But she was strong. The strongest woman I ever knew. Every morning she got up, drank her tea, and held the village together. For thirty years.

hilde_5c.text: ...Yes. But not of what you think. She was afraid she would not see you again. And that you would receive her letter too late.

narration_hilde_silence.text: For a moment I cannot speak. The lump in my throat is too large. Hilde lays a warm hand on my arm and waits.

hilde_6.text: Your grandmother was a clever woman. The cleverest in the village. She knew what was coming. And she made preparations.

hilde_8.text: Drink the tea, Elise. It will protect you. For a while, at least.

elise_hilde_tea.text: What is in the tea? Forgive me, but in this village I trust no one blindly.

hilde_8b.text: Suspicious. Good. You will need that here. Yarrow, mugwort, and valerian. Nothing dangerous. Your grandmother drank the same tea.

hilde_9.text: The tea tastes bitter and earthy. But as I drink, I feel a strange warmth spreading in my chest. The fear of last night recedes a little further.

elise_hilde_effect.text: How did she do that? The fear is not gone — but it is quieter. As though someone had turned a dial.

hilde_10.text: There are old ways and new ways. The pastor tries with prayers. But what sleeps beneath the church is older than his God. It requires older means.

elise_hilde_folklore.text: Old ways... You mean pre-Christian rituals? I study folklore in Berlin. I know the stories — the spirals, the earth mother, the threshold nights.

hilde_10b.text: Stories? Child, what sleeps beneath the church is no story. But yes — you know more than most people here. That is good. That will help you.

hilde_12.text: Your grandmother knew both ways. She waited and prepared for thirty years. She wanted to do it differently this time — without bloodshed.

hilde_13.text: But time caught up with her. Now you are here. And the question is: Are you ready to do what she could no longer do?

elise_hilde_answer.text: I do not know if I am ready. But I am here. And I will not run away.

hilde_13b.text: It was enough for your grandmother. It will be enough for you. Come back to me when you have learned more. There is much I still have to show you.

journal_hilde.title: Hilde, the Herbalist
journal_hilde.content: Hilde knows the 'old ways' — pre-Christian rituals. Grandmother worked on a plan for 30 years to perform the ritual this time without sacrifice. Hilde seems to be an ally.

school_1.text: The schoolhouse stands beside the church. A small building with large windows through which I can see children sitting at wooden benches.

school_2.text: At the blackboard stands a man, explaining something. The children call him 'Herr Müller'. Konrad Müller — the man from last night. In daylight he looks... normal. Friendly. Even charismatic.

school_3.text: When he notices me at the window, he smiles and waves me inside. The children turn around. Not one of them smiles.

elise_school_hesitate.text: Georg said I should stay away from him. But I need to understand this man. Someone who knocks on strangers' doors at night has reasons. I want to hear his.

konrad_day_1.text: Fräulein Brandt! Children, this is Fräulein Brandt, the granddaughter of Frau Margarethe. She is a student in Berlin. From Berlin! Imagine that.

elise_school_greet.text: Good day. The children seem very... attentive.

konrad_day_2.text: The children stare at me. Silent faces, old eyes in young bodies. A girl in the back row is drawing — I can see it from here. Spirals. Over and over, spirals.

elise_school_spirals_girl.text: The girl in the back row. Her spirals are identical to those on the church headstones. The same rotation, the same density. A child cannot draw that by chance.

konrad_day_3.text: Break time, children. Go and play.

konrad_day_4.text: The children stand up and leave — not like children. No hasty movements, no laughter. They walk like small adults. Orderly. Silent.

elise_school_children.text: Are the children here always this... quiet?

konrad_day_4b.text: Graubach children are well-behaved children. The silence here educates them better than any teacher. Some would say they are precocious.

konrad_day_6.text: I am sorry about last night. I hope I did not frighten you. I sometimes take late walks — insomnia, you know.

elise_school_why.text: Why were you outside my door in the middle of the night, Herr Müller? A walk does not lead to a particular front door.

konrad_day_6b.text: When I saw light in Margarethe's house, I wanted to make sure everything was all right. Her house has been empty for three days. One becomes... attentive.

konrad_day_7.text: Your grandmother is missed by the village. She was... an anchor, you know? Some people hold the world together without anyone noticing. Margarethe was one of them.

elise_school_anker.text: An anchor. A strange word. What exactly did she hold together?

konrad_day_7b.text: Everything. She held everything together. More than you realize, Fräulein Brandt.

konrad_day_8.text: He sounds sincere. Even sad. But then he smooths his sleeve, and I see something on his hand. Ink stains? No — the lines are too regular.

konrad_day_9.text: Spirals. On his palm. Carved or drawn, I cannot tell.

elise_school_hand.text: What is that on your hand, Herr Müller?

konrad_day_9c.text: Ink stains. The children work with cheap paper, it rubs off. Nothing more.

narration_konrad_lie.text: He is lying. The lines are too regular, too precise for ink stains. The same spirals as on the headstones, as in Anna's drawings. But his smile remains perfect.

konrad_day_11.text: He notices my gaze and pulls his sleeve over his hand. The smile remains, but something in his eyes changes. Just for a split second.

elise_school_monologue.text: Behind his smile lies something else. Something old. Grandmother wrote he was a 'vessel'. Now, in his eyes, I believe for a moment I can see what she meant.

journal_konrad.title: Konrad Müller, Village Teacher
journal_konrad.content: Konrad is charming and friendly — almost too friendly. The children in his class behave strangely quietly. And on his palm he has spirals. Grandmother wrote that he was a 'vessel'. What really lies behind his smile?

route_next_location.text: The day is still long. I should keep looking around.

choices: Zur Kräuterfrau gehen (Schutz und Großmutters alte Verbündete)
Zum Schulhaus gehen (Konrad und die Spur der Nacht)
Zur Kirche gehen (Voss, Anna und das Geheimnis unter dem Altar)
Zum Schulhaus gehen (Konrad und die Spur der Nacht)
Zur Kirche gehen (Voss, Anna und das Geheimnis unter dem Altar)
Die Kräuterfrau besuchen (Schutz und Großmutters alte Verbündete)

narration_puzzle.text: Voss speaks of 'the Other' beneath the church. Anna sees spirals around me. Konrad HAS spirals on his hand. And Hilde knows the old ways. Everyone speaks in hints. No one tells the whole truth.

converge_1.text: In the early afternoon I go to the fountain. A blind old woman sits on the stone bench beside it, humming softly to herself. The melody seems familiar - the singing I heard last night. She turns her head in my direction, as if she can sense me.

converge_1b.text: Before I can speak to her, she stands and walks away. Slowly, surely, as if she knows every stone. Georg is already waiting at the fountain. He looks as though he, too, did not sleep.

georg_day_1.text: Elise. Did you... was the night quiet?

elise_georg_respond.text: Not really. But you know that, don't you? Konrad Müller was at my door in the middle of the night.

georg_day_2.text: He asks it casually, but his eyes search my face for traces. Traces of what?

elise_georg_report.text: Georg, I looked around the village today. The pastor tells me to flee. His daughter sees things. Hilde speaks of old rituals. And Konrad has spirals on his hand. What is going on here?

georg_react_alarmed.text: Konrad? Did you get close to him? Did he touch you?

elise_georg_no.text: No. But his explanations sound too smooth. And he calls Grandmother an 'anchor'. The same word Hilde used.

georg_day_3.text: Come to my smithy this evening. For supper. I... I owe you some answers.

elise_georg_now.text: Why not now? Why always wait? Everyone in this village speaks in riddles, and you are no better!

georg_day_3b.text: Because walls have ears in Graubach. At my house it is safe. Out here... it is not.

georg_day_5.text: But when you are there — do not speak to anyone about what I tell you. To no one, do you hear?

elise_georg_afraid.text: Georg... do I have a reason to be afraid?

georg_day_5b.text: Georg looks at me for a long time. In his eyes lies something I cannot read. Guilt? Fear? Tenderness?

georg_day_5c.text: Come tonight. Then you will understand everything.

narration_tired_walk.text: My legs are heavy. I have barely slept, barely eaten, and the village presses down on me like a hand on my chest. But I must not show weakness now.

narration_afternoon.text: On the way back to Grandmother's house I pass the graveyard. A man is standing there, before a grave. Heavyset, grey-streaked hair, an expensive coat for such a village.

otto_1.text: Ah, you must be the young Brandt! Welcome to Graubach. I am Otto Reinhardt, mayor of our little village.

elise_otto_greet.text: Mayor Reinhardt. I have already heard about you.

otto_2.text: His voice is loud, jovial. Too loud for a graveyard. Too jovial for a village living in fear.

otto_4.text: Your grandmother was a valued member of our community. We will hold a lovely funeral for her next week. Saturday, after the... after the church service.

elise_otto_nach.text: After the... what exactly, Herr Mayor? You hesitated.

otto_4b.text: After the church service, of course. Saturday is the service. What else?

otto_5.text: He lied. So routinely that it was almost convincing. Almost. But his left eye twitched.

otto_6.text: Do stay until then, Fräulein Brandt. It would not be right to let the granddaughter leave before the funeral. Graubach takes care of its own.

elise_otto_death.text: My grandmother lay alone in her house for three days. In a village where everyone knows everyone. How is that possible, Herr Mayor?

otto_6b.text: A tragic oversight. We all share the blame. But Graubach is a small village — sometimes things happen that should not have happened.

otto_7.text: It sounds like an invitation. But in his eyes I read something else. It is not a wish. It is an expectation.

elise_otto_monologue.text: I say nothing more. But I note his face. The way his smile does not reach his eyes. Otto Reinhardt knows more than anyone else in this village. And he wants me to stay. The question is: Why?

journal_otto.title: Mayor Reinhardt
journal_otto.content: Mayor Otto Reinhardt. Jovial, but with steely control. He wants me to stay until the funeral — 'next week, after the...' He interrupted himself. What takes place before the funeral?

otto_motivation_1.text: On the way back I think about the mayor. About his self-assurance. About the weight of his words — not like a man who threatens, but like one who is absolutely convinced.

otto_motivation_2.text: Georg once told me that Otto's father was mayor in 1893. And his father before him. The Reinhardts have ruled Graubach for generations — and profited from it.

otto_motivation_3.text: The forest protects their land. The harvests on the Reinhardt fields are unnaturally good, even in bad years. The family stays healthy while other children die of fever.

otto_motivation_4.text: Otto does not act only from tradition. He acts from self-interest. And the worst part: he truly believes in it. He is convinced that the sacrifices are necessary. That he is doing the right thing.

otto_motivation_5.text: A madman would be easier. A madman can be exposed. But a true believer? A true believer must be broken.

narration_evening_1.text: The sun sinks behind the mountains. The shadows of the houses grow long and sharp. In a few hours I will be sitting in Georg's smithy and finally getting answers. Or at least what Georg considers answers.

narration_evening_singing.text: On the way to Grandmother's house I hear it again. Faint, almost imperceptible. The singing. It comes from everywhere and nowhere. And for the first time I believe I can make out individual syllables. My name.

konrad_day_trace_1.text: Sie sehen aus, als hätten Sie kaum geschlafen. Manche Gäste verbarrikadieren in der ersten Nacht sogar die Tür. Graubach kann solche Reflexe wecken.

elise_day_trace_2.text: Mein Nacken wird kalt. Von der Mehlspur habe ich niemandem erzählt. Trotzdem legt er das Wort "verbarrikadieren" auf die Zunge, als hätte er zugesehen.

voss_d2_hint.text: In the end she was... strangely calm. As if she had made peace with someone. Not with God. With something else.

narration_1.text: Hours pass. Or minutes. In the glow of the inhuman candle, time loses its meaning.

narration_2.text: I sit at the kitchen table staring at grandmother's notebook. It lies in the bedroom. Georg's words echo in my head.

narration_3.text: "I looked inside. Once. It gave me nightmares."

choices: Get the notebook and read it
Better not. Tomorrow is another day.

read_notebook.text: I go back to the bedroom. The candle flickers as I approach. Grandmother's face is almost alive in the dancing light.

read_notebook_2.text: The notebook is thin but crammed full. The handwriting grows hastier, more frantic from page to page. Some entries are in a language I don't recognize.

read_notebook_3.text: On the first page, neat and clear: "For Elise. When I'm no longer here."

read_notebook_4.text: "There is something beneath the church. Something old. Older than the village, older than the trees, older than the mountains. We call it the Sleeper. My grandmother called it the Breath of the Earth."

elise_nb_react_1.text: Something under the church...? Grandmother, what did you never tell me?

read_notebook_5.text: "Every thirty years it needs... nourishment. The last time was 1893. The next time is now. November 1923."

elise_nb_react_2.text: I set the book down. My hands are trembling too much. Thirty years. Nourishment. What kind of nourishment? I don't want to read on. But I must.

read_notebook_6.text: My hands tremble. I turn the page. The handwriting grows more chaotic.

read_notebook_7.text: "Konrad is not Konrad. Not anymore. Since spring I see it in his eyes. He smiles differently. He moves differently. Something wears him like a coat."

elise_nb_react_3.text: Konrad. The village teacher. I don't know the man - but Grandmother writes about him as if he were a threat. What lives INSIDE a person? What wears someone like a coat?

read_notebook_8.text: "They want you, Elise. Your name is in the book beneath the church. I tried to cross it out, but the ink returns. Again and again."

elise_nb_react_4.text: My name...? MY name is in a book beneath the church? What does that mean? What does this THING want from me?

journal_notebook.title: Grandmother's Notebook
journal_notebook.content: Grandmother writes of something beneath the church — the 'Sleeper'. Every 30 years it needs 'nourishment'. The village teacher Konrad is 'no longer Konrad'. And my name is in a book beneath the church. What does it all mean?

skip_notebook.text: No. Not tonight. Not alone with a corpse and a candle that won't go out.

skip_notebook_2.text: Tomorrow. In daylight. When the world makes sense again.

skip_restless_1.text: But I can't sit still. The silence presses down. I stand up and walk through the dark house, my fingers trailing along the wall.
