skip_restless_2.text: In the hallway I stop. Above the doorframe, symbols are carved into the wood - spirals, intertwined and deep. The same as on the letter. I trace them with my fingers. The wood is smooth, as if Grandmother had retraced them regularly.

skip_restless_3.text: The same at every window. Spirals above the frame, dried bundles of herbs in the cracks. Every opening in the house is protected. Sealed.

skip_restless_4.text: Grandmother... how long have you been doing this? What have you been keeping out?

skip_restless_5.text: At the kitchen window I press my forehead against the cold glass. Outside: darkness. But somewhere in that darkness I feel something. Not see, not hear - feel. As if someone is watching me.

skip_restless_6.text: I return to the table and wrap myself in Grandmother's shawl. The scent of lavender and chamomile envelops me. Almost comforting. Almost.

notebook_converge.text: At some point I must have fallen asleep. At the kitchen table, my head on my folded arms.

narration_dream_1.text: In the dream I stand on the village square. It's night, but the village is brightly lit — by torches arranged in a spiral.

narration_dream_2.text: People stand in a circle. All the villagers. They sing — the same melody I heard on the train. Deep and resonant, as if the sound comes from the earth itself.

narration_dream_3.text: In the center of the circle stands a man. Young, with dark hair and a smile that doesn't match his eyes. He reaches out his hand to me.

narration_dream_4.text: "Welcome back, Elise," he says. "We've been waiting for you."

narration_dream_5.text: Then I hear it. Not the singing, but something beneath it. A deep, rhythmic pounding. Like a heartbeat. But far too large for a human heart.

narration_dream_6.text: The ground beneath my feet begins to vibrate. Cracks run through the cobblestones. Through the cracks comes light — not warm light. Something cold, bluish, moving like something alive.

narration_dream_7.text: And then I open my eyes.

narration_wake_1.text: I jolt awake. It's still dark. My heart hammers.

narration_wake_2.text: And then I hear it. Not in the dream. While awake.

narration_wake_3.text: Singing. Faint, muffled, as if coming from far beneath the house. Many voices, woven into something that isn't quite music and isn't quite language.

narration_singing_2.text: The floorboards vibrate faintly under my bare feet. The glass on the table clinks softly. The candle in the bedroom — I can see it from here — burns higher, brighter.

narration_singing_3.text: Then — a knock at the door.

narration_knock_1.text: Three blows. Slow. Deliberate. Like someone who knows they'll be let in.

narration_knock_3.text: Silence. Then, softly, a voice. Warm, friendly, concerned:

narration_knock_4.text: "Hello? Is anyone there? I saw a light. Do you need help?"

narration_knock_5.text: A man's voice. Young, friendly. Not threatening. But Georg said...

choices: Open the door
Don't open. Georg said so.

open_door.text: My hand is on the bolt. I hesitate. Then I slide it back.

elise_through_door_1.text: Who are you? What do you want in the middle of the night?

voice_reply_1.text: "Konrad Mueller, the village teacher. I saw the light and was worried. Margarethe was... a friend."

elise_through_door_2.text: My uncle said I shouldn't open the door. Not at night.

voice_reply_2.text: A pause. Then, quieter: "Georg is afraid. That's understandable, after what happened. But I'm just a teacher, Fraulein Brandt. Not a monster."

elise_through_door_3.text: How do you know my name? I haven't introduced myself.

voice_reply_3.text: A soft laugh. Warm, but somehow too calm. "Your grandmother talked a lot about you. She was very proud of you. The folklorist in Berlin."

open_door_decide.text: Something in his voice calms me. Against my better judgment, I slide the bolt back and open the door.

open_door_2.text: A man stands at the door. About thirty, with wavy dark hair and brown eyes that shimmer warmly in the moonlight. He wears a coat over a sweater and smiles with concern.

konrad_1.text: Oh — you must be Elise. Margarethe's granddaughter, right? I'm Konrad. Konrad Müller, the village teacher.

konrad_2.text: I'm terribly sorry about your grandmother. She was... a remarkable woman. She often helped me with teaching.

elise_responds_konrad.text: Thank you. Did you know her well?

konrad_3.text: He sounds sincere. His smile is warm, his eyes friendly. And yet — if I look closely, there's something in his gaze. Something that doesn't quite...

konrad_4.text: No. I'm tired and frightened. I'm seeing ghosts.

konrad_notebook_reaction.text: "Konrad is not Konrad. Not anymore." Grandmother's words strike me like lightning. This man — this friendly, smiling man — is supposed to be a vessel?

konrad_continue.text: I just wanted to make sure everything's alright. It's late, and this house... well, it's been empty for days. If you need anything — I live at the schoolhouse, right next to the church.

elise_responds_konrad_2.text: Why are you out in the middle of the night, Herr Mueller? Don't you ever sleep?

konrad_6.text: Sleep well, Elise. And don't worry. Graubach is a quiet village. Nothing ever happens here.

konrad_leave.text: He smiles once more, turns, and disappears into the fog. His footsteps make no sound on the cobblestones.

narration_after_door.text: I close the door. My heart pounds. I don't know if from relief or something else.

narration_after_door_2.text: The singing has stopped. When exactly, I don't know. But now it's silent.

dont_open.text: No. Georg said so. I press my hand over my mouth to make no sound.

elise_thinks_closed.text: Every muscle in me wants to open that door. The voice sounds friendly, concerned, normal. But Georg was terrified. Georg, who tames horses with his bare hands. I stay silent.

dont_open_2.text: Silence. Then, three more blows. Slower this time. More patient.

dont_open_4.text: My name. He knows my name.

elise_thinks_name.text: How? I only arrived today. Nobody knows I'm here - nobody except Georg. Whoever is standing outside this door, he was expecting me.

dont_open_5.text: Through the gap under the door I see a shadow. He stands there, patient, waiting. Minutes pass. Or hours.

dont_open_6.text: Then I hear footsteps retreating. And softly, barely audible, a humming. The same melody.

dont_open_7.text: As the footsteps fade, I notice that the singing beneath the floor has also fallen silent.

converge_night.text: The rest of the night passes in forced wakefulness. I sit with my back to the wall, staring at the door.

converge_night_2.text: At some point the sky outside turns grey. Pale November light seeps through the cracks in the shutters. The night is over.

converge_night_3.text: I'm alive. Everything else can wait until the coffee is brewing.

narration_dawn_1.text: By the stove I find some coffee grounds. My hands tremble as I pour the water. Through the window I see the first faint shimmer above the firs. The village lies silent in the fog, as if nothing had happened.

elise_dawn_plan.text: Today I'll talk to the people here. The pastor, the mayor, anyone who can give me answers. Someone in this village knows what is going on.

narration_dawn_melody.text: But even as I drink the coffee, I hum softly. Without meaning to. The same melody. It has burrowed into me like an earworm that refuses to fade.

journal_night.title: The First Night
journal_night.content: Singing from underground. Knocking at the door. The village has a secret. Grandmother knew it. Georg knows it. And whoever stood at my door — he knew my name.

narration_3_alt.text: Georgs Blick, als er das Notizbuch sah, geht mir nicht aus dem Kopf. Als hätte er darin etwas gesehen, das ihn bis heute verfolgt.

narration_singing_4.text: Dann: drei harte Schläge an der Tür. Auf einmal ist das Summen weg. Kein Beben. Nur mein Atem. War das eben noch der Traum – oder hat er gerade erst angefangen?

door_questions_1.text: Bleiben Sie draußen. Wer sind Sie – und warum sind Sie um diese Uhrzeit hier?

door_questions_2.text: "Konrad Müller. Ich war noch im Schulhaus, dann habe ich Ihren Schrei gehört." Eine Pause. "Ich wollte nur nachsehen, ob Sie verletzt sind."

choices: Tür jetzt öffnen
Trotzdem nicht öffnen

open_door_1b.text: Ich schiebe den Riegel zurück. Die Tür geht auf. Kalte Nachtluft schlägt mir entgegen.

dont_open_tactical_1.text: Ich taste im Dunkeln nach dem Besenstiel hinter der Küchentür und verkeile ihn unter der Klinke. Dann schiebe ich den schweren Stuhl davor. Wenn ich schon nicht kämpfen kann, dann gewinne ich wenigstens Sekunden.

dont_open_tactical_2.text: Aus der Mehldose streue ich eine schmale Linie direkt hinter den Türspalt. Kindisch vielleicht. Aber falls jemand reinkommt, sehe ich Spuren. Ich zwinge meine Hände still zu bleiben, wie Großmutter es beim Nähen getan hat: einatmen auf vier, ausatmen auf sechs.

dont_open_5b.text: Irgendwann knirscht es leise vor der Tür. Nicht wie ein Schritt auf Holz - eher wie Finger, die durch Mehl fahren. Ein langsames Halbkreisgeräusch, dann Stille.

dont_open_5c.text: Ich starre auf die helle Linie am Boden, bis mir die Augen brennen. Erst als draußen wieder Schritte einsetzen, wage ich zu blinzeln.

fortified_door_morning.text: Als ich an der Tür den Stuhl wegziehe, liegt die Mehlspur nicht mehr gerade. Jemand hat in der Nacht eine Spirale hineingezogen - sauber, fast sorgfältig, genau auf der Schwelle. Von außen.

narration_wake_3_hint.text: It doesn't sound angry. It sounds... searching. As if calling for someone who never comes.

narration_1.text: Georg's smithy smells of hot iron and coal. A familiar scent from childhood. Here he once showed me how to forge a nail.

narration_2.text: Tonight the fire has burned low. Georg sits at the table, before him two plates of stew and a jug of beer. He looks ten years older than yesterday.

georg_1.text: Sit down. Eat. And then... then I will tell you what I can.

elise_sit.text: I don't want half-truths, Georg. Not anymore. From anyone.

narration_3.text: We eat in silence. The stew tastes of nothing. Or perhaps it is I who can no longer taste anything.

georg_3.text: In Graubach there is a tradition. As old as the village itself. Older, perhaps. The elders pass it down from generation to generation.

elise_tradition_1_hilde.text: Tradition? What kind of tradition? Hilde spoke of it too.

elise_tradition_1_nohilde.text: Tradition? What kind of tradition? Grandmother hinted at something like that in her letter.

georg_4.text: Every thirty years, in November, when the nights grow longest... a price must be paid.

elise_tradition_2.text: Every thirty years? Georg, that sounds like superstition. Like an old tale that peasants tell each other.

georg_4b.text: You saw the candle. The one in Margarethe's bedroom. It has been burning for days and doesn't get shorter. Is THAT superstition?

elise_tradition_3.text: I want to object. But he's right. The candle burns. The singing comes from beneath the earth. And Anna saw something around me that no child could invent.

georg_5.text: The old folk call it the 'Feeding'. The mayor calls it 'tradition'. Your grandmother called it murder.

elise_mord_react.text: The word hits me like a blow. My spoon clatters against the plate.

elise_mord_react_2.text: Murder? Georg, listen to yourself! What are you saying?

georg_5b.text: The truth. You didn't want half-truths, so you'll get the whole truth.

georg_7.text: And she was right. It is murder, Elise. Every time they choose someone. Someone whose name is written in the book. They lead him into the chamber beneath the church, and...

georg_8.text: He breaks off. His hands grip the beer jug so tightly that the knuckles stand out white.

georg_9.text: He does not come back. No one ever comes back.

elise_wer.text: Who? Who was the last victim?

georg_10.text: The last time was 1893. My grandfather... he was a young man then. He saw it. He never spoke of it, but he never laughed again either.

elise_scale.text: 1893. Thirty years. That means 1863. And before that. And before that. How many people has this village sacrificed? How many generations have kept silent?

choices: Is my name in that book?
Why does no one stop this? Why does no one go to the police?
What is this 'something' beneath the church?

georg_name_1.text: Georg looks at me. The answer is in his eyes before he speaks it.

georg_name_3.text: Your grandmother found out years ago. She tried to cross it out, to burn it away, to tear out the page. But the name always comes back.

georg_name_4.text: That is why she worked for thirty years. On another way. A ritual that binds the entity without demanding a sacrifice.

georg_police_1.text: Police? Elise, the nearest police post is two days' travel away. And even then — what should I tell them? That a monster lives under our church?

elise_police_react.text: That people are disappearing! That's enough!

georg_police_2.text: Besides... whoever does not believe in the tradition disappears. Not in the chamber. Just like that. In the forest, on the road, in the night. The mayor sees to it.

georg_police_3.text: This village is a prison, Elise. And the wardens wear no uniform.

georg_wald_1.text: But how? The postman comes through. Merchants travel through. Why does the forest hold me but not others?

georg_wald_2.text: The forest lets most people pass. Merchants, travelers, even the postman. But those whose names are in the book... it does not let them go.

georg_wald_3.text: That is why I cannot flee.

georg_wald_4.text: Your grandmother tried to leave the village for thirty years. Once. Just a single time. The forest led her in circles for three days until she gave up.

georg_entity_1.text: I do not know. Not really. No one knows. We only know that it is old. Older than the forest, older than the mountains.

elise_entity_react.text: In my studies there are reports of such beings. Old gods sleeping in the earth. I always thought they were metaphors.

georg_entity_2.text: It sleeps. Most of the time it sleeps. But every thirty years the sleep grows lighter. It stirs. It dreams. And its dreams... seep upward.

georg_entity_3.text: The singing you heard? Those are its dreams, Elise. It sings in its sleep.

georg_name_reveal.text: Georg is silent for a moment. Then he rubs his eyes, as if he has to force himself to continue speaking.

georg_name_reveal_2.text: There's something else you need to know. Your name, Elise. It's in the book. In the book in the chamber.

georg_name_reveal_3.text: Your grandmother tried to erase it. Cross it out, burn it out, tear out the page. But the name keeps coming back.

elise_breakdown_2.text: I stand up. The chair scrapes across the stone floor. My heart is hammering so loudly that I'm sure Georg can hear it.

elise_breakdown_4.text: She KNEW? For thirty years she knew that my name was in that damned book? And she told me NOTHING?

georg_defend_1.text: She protected you, Elise. For thirty years she searched for a way to change the ritual. For YOU.

elise_breakdown_5.text: Protected? She lured me into a trap! Her letter, the journey, everything...

georg_defend_2.text: No. She gave you the chance to end it. Not as a victim. As the person who breaks this cycle. Forever.

elise_breakdown_6.text: Silence. Only the crackling of the fire. I sit back down. My hands are trembling. But behind the fear, something else is growing. Something hard.

elise_breakdown_7.text: What did she plan? What exactly do I have to do?

georg_final_1.text: Elise, I have a key. To the chamber beneath the church. Your grandmother entrusted it to me.

georg_final_2.text: He places a heavy iron key on the table. It is old, the teeth worn down. On the grip a spiral is engraved.

elise_key_1.text: I take the key. It's heavier than it looks. The metal is cold, but the spiral on the handle - it feels warm under my fingers. As if something inside it were pulsing.

georg_final_3.text: She wanted you to have it. 'When Elise comes,' she said, 'give her the key. She will know what to do.'

elise_key_2.text: What does she expect of me, Georg? I'm a student. I read books about folklore. I'm not... not a heroine.

georg_final_5.text: But not tonight. And not alone. Promise me that.

elise_key_3.text: But not today. And not alone. Promise me that.

journal_smithy.title: Georg's Confession
journal_smithy.content: Every 30 years a sacrifice — the 'Feeding'. My name is in the book. Grandmother worked on an alternative ritual. Georg gave me the key to the chamber. I must find out what Grandmother planned.

narration_deliberate_1.text: Outside it has grown dark. The lanterns in the smithy cast dancing shadows. The key sits heavy in my coat pocket.

narration_deliberate_2.text: My mind says: Run. Pack your things and run. You're not a folklorist studying an old ritual. You are the VICTIM of a ritual.

narration_deliberate_3.text: But the key in my pocket is warm. And Grandmother's voice is in my head, as clear as if she were standing beside me: 'You are my light against the darkness.'

narration_deliberate_4.text: For thirty years she fought. For me. Should I now flee and make her struggle meaningless?

choices: Stay in Graubach and investigate
Try to flee — tomorrow at dawn

stay_decision.text: Flee? No. Grandmother called me here. She fought for thirty years. I will not run away.

stay_2.text: Besides — if my name is in that book, running will change nothing. The letter found me in Berlin. Whatever it is, it knows where I am.

stay_3.text: Tomorrow I'll need Hilde's herbs, Voss' knowledge of the chamber, and every scrap of information Grandmother left behind. There is a plan. I just have to find it.

flee_decision.text: Enough. I am a student, not a heroine. Tomorrow at dawn I leave. On foot, if I must.

flee_2.text: But as I walk back to Grandmother's house, I notice that the forest stands closer than this morning. The trees at the edge of the village — they were not so dense. Not so near.

flee_3.text: And on the road by which the carriage came lies a fallen tree. A huge, ancient tree. It looks as if it had grown there.

flee_4.text: Graubach does not want to let me go.

flee_5.text: I try another way. The path to the neighboring village. But the trees stand so close together here that barely any moonlight gets through. And between the trunks... something moves.

flee_7.text: I walk faster. Then I run. But every path leads back to the village. Every crossroads ends in a dead end of trees that weren't there yesterday.

flee_8.text: Graubach doesn't want to let me go.

flee_9.text: Breathing heavily, I stand in front of Grandmother's house again. The key in my pocket pulses warm, as if to say: You know what you have to do.

narration_end_1.text: The second night in Graubach falls. The candle in Grandmother's bedroom keeps burning. The singing from the depths begins earlier than yesterday.

narration_end_2b.text: I lie in bed, the key in my hand. The spiral presses into my palm. The singing forms words I can almost understand. Almost.

narration_1.text: The inside of grandmother's house has barely changed. The same dark wooden furniture, the same crocheted blankets.

narration_2.text: But the smell is different. Beneath the familiar scent of chamomile tea and beeswax lies something sweet. Something I can't place.

narration_3.text: In the bedroom she lies. Grandmother Margarethe. The blanket is pulled up to her chin, as if someone carefully tucked her in.

narration_4.text: Her eyes are closed. Her mouth smiles faintly. But her skin has the color of old parchment, and when I touch her hand, it's cold as stone.

narration_4b.text: That smile. It doesn't look like the peaceful death of an old woman. It looks like the smile of someone who finished something. Something important.

narration_grief_2.text: My knees give way. I sink onto the edge of the bed and hold her cold hand in both of mine. My fingers tremble. Tears run down my face before I notice it.

narration_grief_3.text: The last time I held this hand was ten years ago. At the station in Waldkirch, when grandmother slipped dried arnica into my bag as a farewell. "Come back soon," she had said. "Promise me."

narration_grief_4.text: I promised. And then came the university, the seminars, the inflation, and always a reason not to go. Ten years of excuses.

elise_grief_5.text: I'm sorry. I'm so sorry that I didn't come sooner.

narration_grief_6.text: I wipe my eyes. My gaze falls on the nightstand, and through the veil of tears I see three things standing there.

narration_5.text: On the nightstand are three things: a candle, burning. A glass of cloudy water. And a small notebook with a leather cover.

narration_6.text: The candle. It's burning. For three days, if the neighbors are right.

books_reaction.text: In my books it says that burning candles beside the dead mark the transition. Some traditions believe the flame keeps the soul in place until unfinished business is done.

books_reaction_2.text: But no candle burns for three days without being refilled. This one is barely shorter than a new one.

elise_books_react.text: Three days... No candle burns for three days. Not without help. In Black Forest traditions there are soul-lights that only go out when the dead find their peace.

cross_reaction.text: Instinctively I reach for the chain around my neck, where Mother's crucifix hangs. The wood is warm under my fingers — warmer than it should be.

cross_reaction_2.text: Beside the bed I murmur a prayer. The words feel foreign in this room. As if they don't belong here.

elise_cross_react.text: Something in this room doesn't feel right. The crucifix is warm. The air is heavy. And this candle... it should have gone out long ago.

camera_reaction.text: My first instinct is to raise the camera. To capture the scene. But then I lower it again. Some things don't belong on film.

camera_reaction_2.text: Still — the candle. I photograph it up close. Through the viewfinder I see something I hadn't noticed with the naked eye: The wax doesn't drip downward. It spirals around the candle.

elise_camera_react.text: The wax spirals... like the symbol on the letter. That's no coincidence. Something is keeping this flame alive.

general_reaction.text: A shiver runs down my spine. The candle flickers, though there's no draft in the room. The flame bends — toward me.

elise_general_react.text: I take a step back. The flame follows my movement. Impossible. And yet it happens, right before my eyes.

meet_georg.text: Behind me, the wooden floor creaks. I spin around.

narration_georg_1.text: A man stands in the doorframe. Tall, broad-shouldered, with hands like shovels. His face is weathered, his eyes tired.

narration_georg_2.text: Uncle Georg. Grandmother's only son. The blacksmith of Graubach.

elise_sees_georg.text: Georg...? You look... you look terrible.

georg_2.text: He says only my name. But in that one word lies so much — relief, guilt, and something that sounds like fear.

elise_responds_1.text: When did she die? What happened?

georg_3.text: You came. I had hoped... and at the same time feared that you would.

georg_5.text: Your grandmother... I'm sorry, child. We found her like this three days ago. Peaceful, people say. In her sleep.

elise_responds_2.text: Three days? Why didn't anyone let me know? I could have come right away!

georg_explains.text: There's no telephone in Graubach. And the nearest telegraph is in Freiburg. Elise, I didn't want you to come here alone. Not now.

georg_6.text: But her face... she was smiling, Elise. As if she knew something that we don't.

elise_responds_3.text: She was smiling...? Grandmother never smiled in her sleep. Never. What did she see?

narration_elise_looks.text: I look back into the bedroom. Grandmother's smile in the candlelight. It doesn't look peaceful. It looks knowing. As if she had set something in motion that now takes its course.

choices: Who sent the letter? It was postmarked today.
Why is the candle still burning after three days?
What are those notes on the nightstand?

georg_letter_2.text: I show him the envelope. Georg turns pale. His large hands tremble as he touches it.

georg_letter_3.text: That's... that's her handwriting. But Elise — we don't have a post office in Graubach. Not anymore. And the nearest one is two days' journey away.

elise_letter_react.text: Kein Postamt? Aber der Stempel ist von heute, Georg. Der Brief war warm, als ich ihn öffnete. Er roch nach ihren Kräutern. Wie kann eine Tote einen Brief verschicken?

georg_letter_exclusive.text: Things happen in Graubach that shouldn't happen. The letter is still the most harmless of them. Believe me, Elise.

georg_candle_1.text: The candle... Yes. We tried to put it out. On the first day already.

georg_candle_2.text: Georg swallows hard. He looks at the candle like an enemy he cannot defeat.

georg_candle_3.text: It won't go out, Elise. We blew, poured water over it, cut the wick. The next morning it was burning again.

elise_candle_react.text: That's impossible. Candles go out when you cut the wick. That's... Georg, that defies all physics.

georg_candle_4.text: Don't put it out. Please. I don't know why, but... don't put it out.

georg_candle_exclusive.text: The evening before she died, Margarethe lit the candle. She said: "This flame is for Elise. It will burn until she comes." I thought she was talking nonsense. But here you are. And the candle burns.

georg_notes_1.text: Don't touch those! Not... not now.

georg_notes_2.text: Georg flinches, startled, as if he hadn't expected to react so strongly. He runs a hand over his face.

georg_notes_3.text: Forgive me. It's... your grandmother wrote a lot in the last weeks. Day and night. As if time were running out for her.

elise_notes_react.text: Nightmares? Georg, I'm a folklorist. I've read hundreds of horror stories. What's in a notebook that gives YOU nightmares?

georg_notes_4.text: I looked inside. Once. It gave me... it gave me nightmares, Elise. But perhaps you're the one who needs to read it.

georg_notes_exclusive.text: She wrote about the teacher. Konrad Mueller. About what... lives INSIDE him. Elise — promise me: stay away from Konrad.

georg_converge.text: Outside it grows dark. The shadows in the room's corners deepen. The candle throws flickering lights on the wall.

sound_bells.text: Then I hear it. The church bell. Once. Twice. Three times.

narration_bells_2.text: It's not a full hour. And the sound is... wrong. Too deep. As if it comes not from the tower but from underground.

georg_react_1.text: Georg freezes. All color drains from his face. He grabs the doorframe as if needing support.

georg_react_2.text: I have to go. Right now.

georg_react_3.text: Elise, listen to me. Stay here tonight. Lock the door. Bar it. And if someone knocks — if someone knocks, don't open.

choices: What's going on, Georg? Tell me the truth!
Where are you going? Can I come with you?
...Alright. I'll stay here.

georg_demand_1.text: The truth? The truth is that I can't tell you everything. Not yet. It wouldn't make sense.

georg_demand_2.text: Tomorrow. Tomorrow we'll have breakfast together, and I'll tell you... as much as I can. But tonight — please, Elise. Trust me.

elise_demand_farewell.text: Tomorrow, Georg. But tomorrow I want the whole truth. No half measures.

georg_follow_1.text: No! Absolutely not. Not at night. Not... you must not go outside at night, Elise. Promise me.

georg_follow_2.text: The fear in his eyes is real. Georg was never a man who scared easily. As a child, I once saw him stop a runaway horse with his bare hands.

elise_follow_farewell.text: I promise. But you — be careful too. Please.

georg_quiet.text: Georg looks at me. A long moment. Then he nods, and I see relief in his eyes — and at the same time, deep sadness.

georg_quiet_2.text: You're like your grandmother. Stronger than you know.

elise_quiet_farewell.text: I say nothing. But as the door closes, I place my hand against it. On the other side I hear Georg pause. A moment. Then his footsteps recede, heavy and slow.

narration_alone_1.text: The door falls shut. I slide the bolt, as Georg said.

narration_alone_2.text: Alone. With my grandmother's body. And a candle that won't go out.

narration_alone_3.text: Outside it's completely dark now. No light comes through the shutters. No moon, no stars. Only the heavy, saturated blackness of a November evening in the Black Forest.

narration_alone_search_1.text: I can't sleep. Not now. Instead I walk through the house. Grandmother's wardrobe: her scarf, still smelling of lavender. Knitting needles with half-finished work, as if she had only paused briefly.

narration_alone_search_2.text: In a drawer: dried herbs in linen sachets, candle stubs with strange notches, a bundle of yellowed letters. And beneath — my childhood drawings. She kept them all.

elise_finds_photo.text: Behind the drawings is a photograph. Me, perhaps seven years old, on grandmother's lap. Both of us laughing. Summer light falls through an open window.

narration_photo.text: On the back, in grandmother's handwriting: "My light against the darkness." The word "light" is underlined. Three times.

elise_cries.text: I'm here, grandmother. Too late... but I'm here.

narration_alone_4.text: I sit at the kitchen table. Grandmother's teapot is still there, half full. Beside it, a half-eaten piece of bread, hard as wood.

narration_alone_5.text: Three days. She's been dead for three days, but the letter was postmarked today. The candle still burns. And the church bells ring at no hour.

narration_alone_sounds.text: At some point in the silence I hear it. Soft, deep, barely more than a vibration in the floorboards. Singing? No — more like a hum. Like a lullaby that comes from the ground itself.

elise_alone_resolve.text: Tomorrow. Tomorrow I'll start to understand.

journal_grandmother.title: Grandmother Margarethe
journal_grandmother.content: Grandmother is dead. Three days ago, Georg says. But the letter arrived today. The candle by her bed can't be extinguished. Georg is afraid — truly, deeply afraid. What is he hiding?

journal_georg_entry.title: Uncle Georg
journal_georg_entry.content: Georg has changed. Older, more tired, guilt-ridden. He warned me about the night, wouldn't say why. The church bells frightened him — as if they were a signal.

narration_alone_sounds_hint.text: It doesn't sound threatening. It sounds... sad. Like someone sitting alone in a dark room, humming to themselves because no one is listening.

georg_5_hint.text: Only... her boots were by the door. Covered in mud. Even though she had been too weak to walk for a week. I don't know where she went that last night.

narration_1.text: I look at Konrad. He is trembling. Beads of sweat on his forehead. Behind his eyes, a man fights against an ocean.

narration_1_helped_konrad.text: In the schoolhouse he asked for help when he could barely speak. That promise stands between us now like a burning line.

narration_1_distanced_konrad.text: I kept my distance to protect the plan, ever since the square, when something older spoke through him. But now I am here to free him anyway.

narration_2.text: He taught me to read — no, that was Grandmother. He showed me the guardian tree. He asked for help when no one else did.

narration_3.text: And I read in Grandmother's journal what the vessel is: a bridge. The entity has relied on a human mind as an anchor in our world. Without that bridge, it thrashes, reaches, and drags others down.

narration_chose_sacrifice_callback.text: This time the decision was not made by a book, not by Otto, and not by tradition. I made it myself.

konrad_sacrifice_1.text: Elise... please don't do it. I can bear it. I have borne it for thirty years.

elise_sacrifice_1.text: No one should HAVE to bear it. Neither you nor anyone else.

narration_4.text: Konrad was never the vessel willingly. He was chosen before he was born. Selected like a sacrificial lamb.

elise_sacrifice_2.text: I choose it freely. That is the difference. Grandmother taught me that courage is not the absence of fear. It is the decision to act regardless.

narration_5.text: I step onto the earth sign. I open my mind — not to bind the entity or to worship it, but to make a chosen offer. Into me, on terms I can still speak.

elise_sacrifice_3.text: Come. I am ready. Take me instead of him.

narration_creature_sacrifice.text: WHY? WHY DO YOU GIVE YOURSELF WILLINGLY?

elise_sacrifice_4.text: Because no one should be alone. Not even you. And because Konrad deserves to be free.

narration_creature_sacrifice_2.text: YOU ARE LIKE HER. THE OLD ONE. SHE WOULD HAVE DONE THE SAME. BUT SHE WAS TOO OLD. TOO TIRED. YOU ARE... YOUNG. WARM.

narration_6.text: 'I promised to give you your life back, Konrad. This is me keeping it.' My voice sounds calm. Calmer than I feel.

narration_7.text: The entity moves. I feel it — like water flowing from one vessel into another. Out of Konrad, through the stone, into me.

narration_8.text: It is... not as expected. No pain. No horror. It is like an ocean pouring into a pond. Too vast, too old, too different. But it fits. Somehow.

narration_8b.text: I feel its loneliness. Six hundred years, imprisoned in darkness, with nothing but the hunger and the singing. And now... now there is light. My light.

konrad_3.text: Konrad's eyes become clear. For the first time in his life, completely clear. And they fill with tears.

sacrifice_sought_konrad_memory.text: I hear his words from the schoolhouse again — help me before it has me completely. Seeking him out was risky, but that look carried me all the way to this altar.

sacrifice_avoided_konrad_memory.text: I avoided him to protect the plan. That distance hurt us both — and that is exactly why I know what this freedom costs, and why I owe it to him.

konrad_trusted_sacrifice.text: You believed me. At the village square, when all the others feared me. You looked at me and saw a person, not a monster.

konrad_tested_sacrifice.text: You did not trust me blindly. Since that evening with the spirals, you weighed every reaction so caution would not turn into coldness. And still you do this for me.

konrad_distrusted_sacrifice.text: You kept me at arm's length to protect your plan. After what spoke through my mouth at the fountain, that was not betrayal — it was self-protection. And now you still give everything to set me free.

konrad_untrusted_sacrifice.text: You barely knew me. And yet... why? Why for me?

elise_sacrifice_5.text: Because you deserve to be free. Because Grandmother would have wanted us to choose, not obey. And because I can set boundaries with it — no access without consent, no coercion, stop at any time — without making you pay for it any longer.

konrad_5.text: I will never forget what you have done. Never.

elise_sacrifice_6.text: Live your life, Konrad. You have lost thirty years. Take them back.

georg_sacrifice_1.text: Elise, no! You can't — this is madness! There must be another way!

elise_georg_sacrifice.text: It is not madness, Georg. It is a decision. My decision. Take care of the village.

hilde_sacrifice_1.text: You are braver than your grandmother. She would have done it if she could have. I bless you, child.

voss_sacrifice_1.text: God be with you, child. What you are doing is... holy. In a way that no prayer can reach.

elise_voss_sacrifice.text: Pray for me, Pastor. Not for my soul. For my strength.

narration_sacrifice_solo.text: Silence. Only the singing — softer now, more content. No one is here to stop me. No one to comfort me. Only me and the entity that slowly finds its new place.

sacrifice_fallout_intro.text: Bevor wir die Kammer verlassen, holt uns der Abend von gestern ein: die harten Worte, der Riss zwischen uns, alles noch offen.

sacrifice_rehearsed_payoff.text: Wir fallen automatisch in die geübten Zeichen zurück: ein Blick, ein kurzes Nicken, klare Sätze statt Vorwürfe. Die Probe von gestern hält uns heute zusammen.

sacrifice_skipped_rehearsal_cost.text: Die fehlende Probe hängt uns nach. Zweimal reden wir aneinander vorbei, bis Konrad uns hart stoppt und jeder nur einen Satz sagt. Erst dann wird aus Panik wieder ein Plan.

sacrifice_georg_reconcile.text: Ich war gestern nur noch Zorn. Heute sehe ich, dass du uns trotzdem vertraut hast, Elise. Wenn du bleibst, bleibe ich auch - als jemand, der mitträgt statt drängt.

sacrifice_hilde_reconcile.text: Auch ich war hart zu dir, Kind. Nicht weil ich dich klein sah, sondern weil ich Angst hatte, dich zu verlieren. Ab jetzt singen wir nicht gegeneinander, sondern mit dir.

sacrifice_voss_reconcile.text: Ich habe mein schlechtes Gewissen gestern als Rat verkleidet. Das war feige. Heute sage ich es klar: Danke, dass du uns nicht aus der Verantwortung entlässt.

sacrifice_fallout_outro.text: Kein großes Happy End. Aber wir gehen die Stufen hinauf, ohne dass jemand zurückbleibt. Für Graubach ist das fast schon ein Wunder.

narration_10.text: I do not finish the sentence. The words no longer belong to me alone. In my head, beside my thoughts, the singing softly begins.

narration_11.text: Konrad takes my hand. He weeps. I smile. It is not my smile alone — but it is real.

narration_12.text: I will stay in Graubach. I take Konrad's place — as teacher and guardian of the boundary. Not as a mindless vessel, but as a negotiating partner with clear rules: no access without consent, no coercion, stop at any time.

anna_sacrifice_1.text: Days later, I find Anna in front of the schoolhouse. She is drawing — no longer spirals. Flowers. Trees. Normal things.

anna_sacrifice_2.text: The singing has grown quieter, Elise. Since you've been here. It is... more content. You are a better home than Konrad.

elise_anna_sacrifice.text: It has someone to talk to. For the first time in six hundred years.

anna_sacrifice_3.text: You are a better home than Konrad. It likes you.

elise_anna_2.text: And I... I think I like it too. In a strange, inhuman way.

narration_13.text: The entity and I will learn to coexist. Two consciousnesses in one body. It will not be easy. But it is better than six hundred years of blood.

narration_14.text: Grandmother, you taught me not to fear the unknown. Now I live with the unknown. Literally.

narration_15.text: The singing in my head grows softer. Gentler. Almost like a lullaby. Perhaps it is one.

journal_sacrifice.title: The Sacrifice
journal_sacrifice.content: I have taken Konrad's place as vessel. Willingly. The entity and I now share one body, one mind. It is not the end. It is the beginning of a coexistence.

packed_books_sacrifice.text: My books now stand on Grandmother's shelf. Elise reads them sometimes, when the entity sleeps. Folklore has taken on a new meaning - no longer study. Living experience.

packed_cross_sacrifice.text: The crucifix hangs above the bed. Sometimes, when the entity gazes at the cross through Elise's eyes, she feels its curiosity. It knows no gods. But it understands the comfort.

packed_camera_sacrifice.text: The camera sits dusty on the shelf. Elise no longer photographs. Why would she? What she sees, no lens can capture. But sometimes, in clear moments, she captures the world in words.

sacrifice_epilog_transition.text: Days become weeks. Weeks become months. I learn to live with my guest. And my guest learns not to devour me.

sacrifice_konrad_tactic_voice.text: Was wir für Konrad geübt hatten - Rhythmus, Atem, klare Einsätze - nutze ich jetzt selbst, wenn die fremde Stimme in mir lauter wird.

sacrifice_konrad_tactic_hand.text: Auch der Handanker hilft: Holzrahmen, kalter Tisch, drei Atemzüge. Dann gehört mein Körper wieder mir.

sacrifice_konrad_tactic_interrupt.text: Das Stoppwort ist kein Wunder. Aber oft reicht genau diese kleine Unterbrechung, um nicht in den Sog zu kippen.

sacrifice_konrad_tactic_anchor_phrase.text: Und der Ankersatz bleibt mein täglicher Check: Wer spricht gerade - ich, oder das, was in mir wohnt?

sacrifice_anna_epilog.text: Anna understands it first. 'The singing sounds different,' she whispers. 'Warmer. Like a conversation.' She places her hand on Elise's shoulder.

sacrifice_anna_warning_payoff.text: You listened when I warned you about him — and later you listened when I said there was still a person inside him. You held both truths. That is why this worked.

sacrifice_mathilde_epilog.text: Mathilde, the blind woman from the train, survived the ritual sixty years ago. Alone, forgotten. I will not be forgotten.

sacrifice_otto_epilog.text: Otto never understands. He leaves because the tradition no longer makes sense. His last glance back is empty.

sacrifice_candle_epilog.text: In Grandmother's house, the candle burns on. But its light is warmer now, more golden. As though it knows that Elise has stayed.

choices: Ein festes Nachritual setzen (Protokoll schreiben, dann Kerze löschen)
Flexibel bleiben und nur auf akute Signale reagieren

sacrifice_daily_anchor_ritual.text: Ich gebe dem Ende eine Form: schreiben, prüfen, erst dann schlafen. Kein Drama - nur Wiederholung, bis aus Überleben wieder Alltag wird.

sacrifice_daily_anchor_flexible.text: Ich halte die Struktur offen und reagiere auf den Tag statt auf ein starres Schema. Freiheit fühlt sich riskanter an - aber auch ehrlicher.

konrad_2.text: Elise, NO! What are you doing?!

narration_9.text: 'Because you deserve to be free. Because Grandmother would have wanted it. And because...'

narration_1.text: Day eight. Sunset. The chamber beneath the church pulses like a heart. The spirals on the walls are turning. The singing fills everything.

narration_2.text: I stand on the earth sign, the point where the stone is thinnest. Beneath my feet I feel it: vast, ancient, awakening.

stance_regelorientiert_ritual.text: Ich gehe den Ablauf im Kopf noch einmal durch: Zeichen prüfen, Stimmen synchronisieren, Abbruchsignal bereit. Ordnung ist heute kein Trost - sie ist Überlebensbedingung.

stance_beziehungsorientiert_ritual.text: Ich denke an die Gesichter über mir: Konrad, die Verbündeten, selbst Otto in seiner Angst. Wenn ich heute handle, dann so, dass danach noch Menschen zueinander finden können.

stance_pragmatisch_ritual.text: Ich sortiere alles auf eine Frage herunter: Was funktioniert in den nächsten Minuten? Kein Pathos, kein Dogma - nur Entscheidungen, die uns lebend bis zum Morgengrauen bringen.

seal_protocol_practiced_payoff.text: Meine Kreidelinie aus der Nacht sitzt noch im Muskelgedächtnis: drei Atemzüge, ein Einsatz, ein klares Stopp-Zeichen. Der Ablauf ist nicht hübsch, aber belastbar.

understand_questions_prepared_payoff.text: In meiner Tasche knistert der gefaltete Zettel mit den drei Fragen. Als das Summen in meinem Kopf anschwillt, zwingt mich die Reihenfolge zurück in Sprache statt Panik.

destroy_charge_prepared_payoff.text: Ich sehe die Kreidemarkierung zum Treppenansatz sofort wieder. Wenn heute etwas reißt, verliere ich keine Sekunden mit Stolz. Ich kenne meinen Rückzugspfad.

pact_terms_written_payoff.text: Die Paktklauseln liegen nicht nur in meinem Kopf, sondern schwarz auf Papier neben dem Journal. Falls ich schwanke, verhandle ich nicht aus Stimmung, sondern aus klaren Sätzen.

bridge_fallout_seen_memory.text: Auf der Brücke ist alles endgültig geworden. Worte wurden zu Wunden, Loyalität zu Entscheidung. Seitdem weiß ich, was diese Nacht jeden kosten kann.

rehearsed_signal_ritual_memory.text: Bevor es ernst wurde, haben wir den Notablauf trocken geübt - Schläge, Atem, Einsatz. Jetzt, im Lärm der Kammer, liegt der Rhythmus schon in meinem Körper. Ich muss ihn nur abrufen.

skipped_rehearsal_ritual_memory.text: Wir haben auf die Probe verzichtet. Jetzt muss ich jedes Zeichen unter Druck neu sortieren, während die Stimme unter dem Stein drängt. Jeder Atemzug kostet mehr Konzentration als geplant.

reached_chamber_memory.text: Nicht zum ersten Mal. Ich erinnere mich an den ersten Abstieg in diese Tiefe: dieselbe warme Luft, derselbe Druck im Kopf, derselbe Moment, in dem klar wurde, dass man hier unten nicht gewinnen kann, indem man so tut, als wäre alles normal.

narration_3.text: Georgs Schlüssel hat die letzte Tür geöffnet. Hildes Kräuter brennen in einer Schale neben mir, ihr Rauch steigt spiralförmig auf. Großmutters Journal liegt aufgeschlagen.

narration_4.text: Großmutters Brief in meiner Brusttasche. Hildes Amulett um meinen Hals. Alles, was mich mit den Lebenden verbindet.

study_memory_line.text: Ich sehe wieder Großmutters Schreibtisch vor mir: Karten, Notizen, spiralförmige Skizzen bis in den Rand. Ihr Verstand hat mir den Weg in diese Kammer gezeichnet.

cellar_memory_line.text: Kalter Stein, der Geruch von Kräutern, die Blechdose hinter der losen Mauer: In der Tiefe des Hauses begann mein Abstieg lange vor dieser Nacht.

anna_spirale_memory.text: Ich sehe Annas Kreidezeichnung vor mir: Spirale über Spirale, ein Kreis im Kreis - genau wie hier im Stein. Ein Kind hat erkannt, was die Erwachsenen verschwiegen haben.

bedroom_memory_line.text: Unter der Diele neben Großmutters Bett - dort, wo früher Süßigkeiten lagen - fand ich ihre letzten Aufzeichnungen. Selbst jetzt fühlt sich das an wie eine Umarmung aus der Vergangenheit.

anchor_memory_line.text: Hilde hatte recht: Der Anker ist keine Kette, sondern eine Beziehung. Großmutter hat es getragen, und jetzt liegt diese Rolle bei mir.

death_memory_line.text: "Und wenn ich sterbe?" hatte ich Hilde gefragt. Ihre Antwort dröhnt noch in mir nach. Angst ist erlaubt - weglaufen nicht.

found_name_memory.text: Und da ist diese Erinnerung: mein eigener Name in diesem Buch, schwarz wie frische Tinte. Seitdem fühlt sich jeder Schritt hierher wie etwas an, das längst entschieden wurde.

erase_name_memory.text: Ich habe versucht, meinen Namen aus den Seiten zu kratzen. Die Tinte ließ sich nicht bewegen - nur meine Finger blieben schwarz. Manche Dinge wollen gelesen werden.

narration_5.text: Now there is no turning back. The entity knows I am here. It is waiting.

book_taken_narration.text: The book in my hands pulses. It is warm, alive, as though it had its own heartbeat. The creature recognizes it immediately.

book_taken_creature.text: YOU BROUGHT IT. MY BREATH. MY MEMORY.

book_taken_reaction.text: The book vibrates in my hands. The pages turn by themselves — names, hundreds of names, in an ink that glows in the dark.

book_left_narration.text: On the pedestal in the corner lies the book. I did not take it back then. The creature senses my gaze upon it.

book_left_creature.text: YOU LEFT IT. THAT WAS... WISE. OR FEAR.

book_left_reaction.text: The book remains closed. But the spiral on the cover turns slowly, as though watching me.

georg_ritual_trust_line.text: Du hast mir dein Leben anvertraut, Elise. Das vergesse ich nicht.

georg_ritual_hurt_line.text: Ich war gestern wütend, dass du mich erst draußen lassen wolltest. Bin ich ehrlich. Aber Wut ist kein Grund, dich heute allein in diese Kammer gehen zu lassen.

georg_ritual_1.text: I am here, Elise. As promised.

elise_georg_ritual.text: Whatever happens, Georg — thank you. For everything. For Grandmother. For me.

georg_ritual_2.text: Thank me afterwards. When we walk out of here. Together.

hilde_ritual_trust_line.text: Du hast auf eine alte Frau gehört, als alle anderen nur Angst hatten. Das war klug - und mutig.

hilde_ritual_hurt_line.text: Gestern hat deine Entscheidung gestochen, Kind. Ich wäre gern näher bei dir gewesen. Aber Kränkung ist kein Orakel - heute zählt nur, dass du lebend wieder hinausgehst.

hilde_ritual_entry_1.text: The herbs are burning properly. Good. The smoke will open the way.

elise_hilde_ritual.text: Hilde... if I don't come back...

hilde_ritual_entry_2.text: You will come back. Your grandmother promised me that, and Margarethe never lied.

voss_ritual_trust_line.text: Sie haben einem gebrochenen Priester vertraut. Dafür schulde ich Ihnen heute mehr als ein Gebet.

voss_breath_litany_ritual_payoff.text: Mit mir, Elise. Vier ein, vier halten, vier aus. Kein Heldentakt - nur Atem. Wir haben das geübt.

voss_truth_litany_ritual_payoff.text: Ich wiederhole unseren Satz, Pfarrer: Ich bin nicht allein in dieser Kammer. Nicht heute. Nicht mit Ihnen hier.

voss_ritual_hurt_line.text: Gestern klang in mir noch Enttäuschung. Heute bleibt davon nur Scham. Ich habe zu oft zugesehen, während andere hinabstiegen. Das wiederhole ich nicht.

voss_ritual_1.text: Heavenly Father, stand by this child in her darkest hour...

elise_voss_ritual.text: Pastor. If your God has power down here — then now.

voss_ritual_2.text: He has power everywhere. Even over things that are older than His name.

narration_alone_ritual.text: I am alone. Just as Grandmother was for thirty years. Perhaps that is the right way. This meeting was always meant for just the two of us.

narration_ally_ready.text: I breathe deeply. The smoke of the herbs fills my lungs. The amulet pulses warm against my chest. It is time.

narration_begin_ritual.text: I place my hands on the earth sign. The pulsing point at the center of the circle. And this time I do not pull them back.

earth_sign_memory.text: Hilde hat mir gezeigt, wie das Zeichen gelesen werden will: nicht als Kreis, sondern als geöffnete Hand. Als Einladung - und als Grenze.

otto_has_book.text: A sound at the entrance. Otto Reinhardt steps from the shadows, the book in his hands. He must have followed me.

otto_book_taunt.text: Otto's lips form a triumphant smile. He raises the book like a weapon - but before he can speak, the air vibrates.

otto_book_creature.text: THE BOOK BELONGS TO ME. NOT TO HIM.

otto_book_taken.text: The book tears itself from Otto's hands, flies through the air, and lands open before me. Otto stumbles back, chalk-white, and flees up the stairs. The entity has no patience for thieves.

packed_books_narration.text: My books lie open beside me. A passage about binding rituals in pre-Christian communities comes to mind — the resonance of the spoken word, the connection between sound and earth.

packed_books_creature.text: YOU CARRY WORDS. WORDS HAVE POWER.

packed_cross_narration.text: My mother's cross pulses in my hand — not divine, but... human. Warm. It protects me for a moment from the overwhelm as the entity's consciousness rolls over me.

packed_camera_narration.text: Through the camera's lens I see it. The connection. Spirals in the air, threads of light between the stones. Visible, tangible. The camera shows what the naked eye cannot grasp.

narration_contact_1.text: The ocean. Again. But this time I am not just a fly on its surface. This time I dive in.

narration_contact_2.text: Cold. Then warmth. Then something beyond temperature. A consciousness that slowly turns around and LOOKS AT ME.

narration_creature_1.text: Then it speaks. Not with words. Not with sounds. It speaks directly into my mind, and the words are older than any language I know.

narration_creature_speak_1.text: I KNOW YOU. YOUR NAME IS WRITTEN IN MY BOOK.

narration_creature_speak_2.text: The voice is like thunder in a closed room. My teeth vibrate. My bones hum.

elise_creature_1.text: I... I know. I know that you know me. I have come to—

narration_creature_speak_3.text: YOU ARE LIKE HER. THE OLD ONE. SHE SMELLED OF HERBS AND STUBBORNNESS. YOU SMELL THE SAME.

narration_creature_react.text: It knows Grandmother. It remembers her. For thirty years she visited it, sang to it, bound it. And it remembers.

knowledge_high.text: Everything I have learned - the spirals, the singing, the old stories - it all makes sense now. The creature is no monster. It is a prisoner. Like Konrad, only older. Much older.

knowledge_high_2.text: I know you. Not your name, but your loneliness. The spirals, the dreams, the singing - I listened.

knowledge_zero.text: Ich verstehe nichts. Das Bewusstsein, das mich berührt, ist so fremdartig, so ANDERS, dass mir die Worte fehlen. Als würde man eine Sprache hören, die nie für menschliche Ohren gedacht war.

elise_creature_2.text: Margarethe. My grandmother. She sent me.

narration_creature_speak_4.text: SHE IS NO MORE. I FELT HER LIGHT GO OUT. IT WAS... QUIET AFTERWARDS.

narration_creature_lonely.text: In the voice there is something I did not expect. Not hunger. Not rage. Grief. This ancient, inhuman entity GRIEVES for my grandmother.

narration_creature_speak_5.text: SHE WAS THE ONLY ONE WHO SANG. NOT OUT OF FEAR. OUT OF... I HAVE NO WORD FOR IT. YOU MIGHT SAY: COMPASSION.

narration_creature_speak_6.text: I AM OLDER THAN YOUR GOD. I WAS HERE BEFORE THE TREES, BEFORE THE MOUNTAINS, BEFORE THE RIVER. AND I AM SO TIRED.

narration_creature_hunger.text: HUNGER IS NOT A WORD. IT IS A VOID. FOR SIX HUNDRED YEARS YOU GAVE ME YOUR DEAD. THEY TASTE OF FEAR. I WANT NO MORE FEAR.

heard_singing_payoff.text: Das ist es also: das Singen aus meiner ersten Nacht. Keine Halluzination, kein Wind in alten Balken - eine Sprache aus Hunger und Bitte. Damals hat es mich nur erreicht. Jetzt antworte ich.

creature_names_1.text: HUNDREDS OF NAMES. NOT ALL VICTIMS. SOME I TOUCHED. SOME TOUCHED ME. VESSELS. SEERS. ONLY EVERY THIRTY YEARS ONE WITH THE CROSS.

creature_margarethe_1.text: THE OLD ONE. SHE CAME TO ME. AT THE END. OF HER OWN WILL. I DID NOT TAKE HER. SHE... SAID FAREWELL.

creature_margarethe_2.text: Grandmother. She died peacefully. She went to the creature of her own will, had her last conversation with it. No murder, no accident. A farewell.

creature_margarethe_3.text: My eyes burn. Grandmother did not have to die alone. She had someone with her — even if that someone was older than humankind.

narration_elise_realization.text: My hands tremble on the stone. But not from fear. From realization. It is not a monster. It is something old and lonely that never had any other choice than to take what was given to it.

elise_creature_4.text: What do you really want? Not sacrifice. Not blood. Say it plainly—what do you need from us?

narration_creature_speak_7.text: FOR SOMEONE TO STAY WITHOUT DYING. TO RETURN BY CHOICE, AND LEAVE BY CHOICE. SIX HUNDRED YEARS AND NOBODY EVER ASKED.

narration_revelation.text: Silence. In my mind, in the chamber, everywhere. The singing has stopped. For the first time since I arrived in Graubach, it is quiet.

narration_revelation_2.text: It is waiting for my answer. The oldest being beneath these mountains is holding its breath for the terms of a conversation no one ever offered.

choices: Erst erden: Hand auf den Stein, Atem zählen, dann sprechen.
Direkt antworten, bevor der Moment wieder kippt.

revelation_grounding_grounded.text: Ich drücke die Hand in die kalte Spirale und zähle zwei Atemzüge, bevor ich den Mund öffne. Der Druck bleibt - aber meine Stimme gehört wieder mir.

revelation_grounding_immediate.text: Ich lasse den Moment nicht erstarren und antworte sofort. Das Risiko ist hoch, aber ich zwinge das Gespräch in Bewegung, bevor die Stille wieder zur Falle wird.

anchor_awareness.text: Hildes Worte schlagen in mir nach: Anker. Verbindung. Kein Zufall. Vielleicht fragt das Wesen nicht irgendeinen Menschen. Vielleicht fragt es genau den, den es seit Jahren gesucht hat.

courage_high_dialogue.text: My hands rest steady on the stone. No trembling. No panic. Only clarity, razor-sharp and cold.

courage_high_2.text: YOU ARE NOT AFRAID. THAT IS... NEW. SIX HUNDRED YEARS AND NO ONE STOOD SO CALM BEFORE ME.

courage_high_3.text: I am afraid. But I have learned that fear need not be the last thing one feels.

courage_low_dialogue.text: My whole body trembles. My teeth chatter. The cold creeps from inside out, as if the entity had pushed a finger of ice into my chest.

courage_low_2.text: YOUR FEAR TASTES LIKE THE OTHERS'. BUT YOU ARE HERE NONETHELESS. THAT MAKES YOU... STRANGE.

courage_low_3.text: I am so afraid. But I cannot leave. Not now. Not after everything.

voss_anchor_memory_global.text: Mitten im Druck fällt mir Voss' Satz wieder ein: Hand auf den Stein. Einen Namen nennen, der mich an die Lebenden bindet. Ich drücke die Finger in die Spirale und flüstere erst 'Margarethe', dann 'Anna'. Die Stimmen werden nicht leiser - aber sie tragen mein Gesicht nicht mehr fort.

konrad_ward_ritual_memory.text: Auf der Treppe höre ich kurz Kreide auf Stein - drei schnelle Striche, dann Stille. Der Schutzkreis an der Schultür hat ihn nicht gerettet, aber vielleicht lang genug gebremst, dass das Wesen nicht beide Orte zugleich halten kann.

konrad_distance_ritual_memory.text: Ich habe mich gestern nicht einmal zur Schultür umgedreht. Jetzt trägt mich genau diese Härte: kein Kontakt, keine Lücke, kein zusätzlicher Weg für ES in meinen Plan.

konrad_distrust_memory.text: Ich habe Konrad auf Abstand gehalten. Nicht grundlos: Am Brunnen kippte seine Stimme in dieses kalte 'ICH lüge nie'. Und trotzdem habe ich ihn gestern im Schulhaus aufgesucht. Jetzt sehe ich den Preis beider Entscheidungen - Distanz hat uns gewarnt, Nähe hält ihn gerade noch bei sich.

konrad_tested_memory.text: Ich habe ihn geprüft statt ihm zu vertrauen: ein beiläufiges Wort über Spiralen, seine Hand sofort am Handgelenk, ein Blick wie ertappt. Gestern im Klassenzimmer bat er mich trotzdem um Hilfe. Jede Frage war ein Messer - aber vielleicht war genau diese Vorsicht der Grund, warum er heute noch gegen das Wesen ankämpft.

konrad_anchor_phrase_ritual_payoff.text: Noch bevor ich ihn sehe, spreche ich leise Annas Drei-Anker-Satz: "Konrad Müller. Lehrer. Klassenzimmer." Kein Zauber, nur Identität. Aber in dieser Kammer ist Identität die schärfste Klinge gegen das Verschlucktwerden.

konrad_missing_time_ritual_payoff.text: Am Brunnen sprach Konrad von fehlender Zeit nach dem Glockenton. Genau daran halte ich mich jetzt: Ich lasse zwischen seinen Blickwechseln keine Lücke, nenne seinen Namen sofort und zwinge die Stille klein zu bleiben.

konrad_spiral_signs_ritual_payoff.text: Ich erinnere mich an seine verkrampften Finger vom Brunnen. Bevor Konrad überhaupt spricht, achte ich auf seine Handgelenke statt auf seine Augen - sobald sie zucken, setze ich den Gegengesang früher an.

konrad_interrupt_word_ritual_payoff.text: Wir haben ein einziges Notwort vereinbart: Mittwoch. Ich lege es mir wie einen Kiesel auf die Zunge - klein, klar, vertraut. Falls er kippt, werfe ich genau dieses Wort in die Stille.

konrad_voice_rhythm_ritual_payoff.text: Im Schulhaus haben wir den Rufrhythmus geübt wie einen Drill. Heute ist er mein Metronom: Name, Ort, Jetzt - ohne Pause, bis seine Pupillen wieder auf mich einrasten.

konrad_hand_anchor_ritual_payoff.text: Ich halte seine Hand so, wie wir es geübt haben: Daumen auf Fingerkuppen, eins bis vier. Kein großes Wunder - nur ein Weg zurück in Fleisch und Atem, bevor ES ihn wieder flachzieht.

konrad_appears.text: Footsteps on the stairs. Konrad. He stands in the entrance of the chamber, half in shadow. His eyes flicker between brown and something bottomless.

konrad_suspicious_memory.text: Ich erinnere mich an jeden falschen Ton, jedes ausweichende Lächeln, an dieses abrupte Wegkippen in die fremde Stimme. Mein Misstrauen war nicht Grausamkeit, sondern ein Frühwarnsystem. Und trotzdem steht er jetzt hier und kämpft - also muss ich beides halten: Distanz im Kopf, Mitgefühl in den Händen.

konrad_knows_plan_memory.text: Du hast mich eingeweiht, Elise. Jedes Mal, wenn ES in meinen Kopf griff, habe ich ihm einen falschen Ort, eine falsche Uhrzeit gegeben. Nicht immer geschafft - aber jede gelogene Minute hat dir diese Nacht gekauft.

konrad_door_memory.text: You opened the door for me when everyone else kept it locked. On the first night. That... that was me, Elise. Not IT. That was me.

konrad_test_payoff.text: Du hast mich damals mit den Spiralen getestet - und gesehen, wie ich sofort ans Handgelenk griff. Gut so. Hier unten sollte man niemandem blind vertrauen, nicht mal mir. Aber du hast aus Vorsicht keinen Vorwand gemacht, wegzusehen. Du bist wiedergekommen.

konrad_1.text: Elise... it brought me here. It... IT SPEAKS THROUGH ME. But a part of me is still here. Still.

elise_konrad_callout_missing_time.text: Konrad, hör auf mich. Wenn die Glocke in deinem Kopf losgeht, folgst du nur meiner Stimme. Keine Stille dazwischen. Bleib hier!

elise_konrad_voice_rhythm_callout.text: Jetzt der Takt, Konrad! Name - Ort - Jetzt. 'Konrad Müller. Unter der Kirche. Jetzt.' Mit mir. Nochmal!

elise_konrad_callout_spiral_signs.text: Konrad! Schau auf deine Hände. Nicht auf ES. Öffne die Finger, eins nach dem anderen. Du bist hier, bei mir, in dieser Kammer!

elise_konrad_hand_anchor_callout.text: Fingeranker, wie geübt! Daumen auf Zeigefinger - Mittelfinger - Ringfinger - kleiner Finger. Zähl mit mir, Konrad. Eins, zwei, drei, vier!

elise_konrad_ritual_1.text: Konrad! Listen to my voice. YOU are Konrad Mueller. You are a teacher. Hold on!

konrad_3.text: It is so tired, Elise. I feel it. Six hundred years of loneliness... no human could endure that. And it is not human.

elise_konrad_ritual_2.text: I know. I heard it. It does not want to feed. It does not want to kill. It just wants someone to stay.

konrad_4.text: For thirty years I HAVE stayed. Not willingly. But I understand it now. The loneliness. The endless, bottomless loneliness.

narration_konrad_choice.text: Konrad's eyes flicker. Brown. Bottomless. Brown. He is fighting against himself. Against the entity. Against thirty years of captivity.

anna_warning_konrad_choice.text: Ich höre Annas Stimme aus dem Wald: 'Beeil dich.' Nicht als Drohung - als letzte Bitte von jemandem, der jeden Tag ein Stück weiter verschwindet und nur bleiben will. Diese Entscheidung betrifft nicht nur Konrad und mich. Sie entscheidet, ob Anna morgen noch Anna ist.

ritual_signal_confident_choice.text: Ich zähle den Takt aus der Probe von gestern leise mit: drei, zwei, eins. Der Ablauf hält. Nicht perfekt - aber stabil genug, um eine klare Entscheidung zu treffen.

ritual_signal_books_context_lock_choice.text: Ich reiße den Blick auf die markierte Passage in meinen Notizen: drei klare Schritte, kein Gedanke dazwischen. Der Lärm bleibt, aber er bekommt Klammern. Genug, um nicht im Geräusch zu versinken.

ritual_signal_unsteady_choice.text: Mir fehlt der eintrainierte Takt. Die Kammer schreit, Konrad schwankt, und ich muss den Ablauf im Kopf zusammensetzen, während die Zeit davonläuft. Jede Option fühlt sich riskanter an.

packed_camera_hint_choice.text: Im Sucher liegt ein kurzes Flackern über der leeren Zeile im Buch, genau dann, wenn Konrads Blick kippt. Das Timing ist der Hebel: erst halten, dann entscheiden. Nicht umgekehrt.

choices: Konrad zuerst stabilisieren (Name-Ort-Jetzt), auch wenn ich dafür einen Herzschlag riskiere.
Kein Zusatzschritt - den schmalen Zeitkorridor sofort in die Grundsatzentscheidung umsetzen.

late_climax_stabilize_result.text: "Konrad Müller. Unter der Kirche. Jetzt." Einmal, klar, ohne Zittern. Sein Blick findet mich für einen Moment - kurz, aber genug, um meine nächste Entscheidung wirklich zu meiner zu machen.

late_climax_rush_result.text: Ich lasse den Impuls, ihn noch einmal zu halten, bewusst los. Der Moment ist schmal wie eine Messerkante; ich nutze ihn, bevor die Kammer ihn wieder zuschlägt.

choices: Take Konrad's place — free him, whatever the cost
Stick to the original plan

late_climax_sacrifice_stabilized.text: Weil sein Blick gerade noch bei mir war, klingt mein Entschluss nicht wie Flucht, sondern wie Antwort.

late_climax_sacrifice_rushed.text: Ich entscheide im Sturzflug durch den Lärm. Kein Sicherheitsnetz - nur Verantwortung.

late_climax_plan_stabilized.text: Ich halte den Plan nicht aus Kälte, sondern weil ich ihn ihm gerade noch ins Gesicht sagen konnte.

late_climax_plan_rushed.text: Der Entschluss fällt hart und sofort. Wenn ich jetzt zögere, trifft der nächste Schlag uns beide unvorbereitet.

sacrifice_decision.text: Konrad. I am taking your place.

elise_sacrifice_2.text: Nobody should be alone. Not even something older than the mountains. And you have suffered for thirty years. That is enough.

narration_sacrifice_creature.text: YOU ARE LIKE HER. THE OLD ONE. SHE WOULD HAVE DONE THE SAME.

choices: Konrad ein letztes klares Versprechen geben, bevor er geht.
Dem Wesen die Bedingungen laut fixieren, bevor ich den Platz übernehme.

sacrifice_closure_konrad_line.text: Hör mir zu, Konrad: Das ist kein Abschied ins Nichts. Du gehst heute hier raus, du schläfst morgen in deinem Bett, und wenn ich kippe, zieht die Stopp-Regel - sofort. Du lässt mich damit nicht allein.

sacrifice_closure_konrad_reply.text: Ich lasse dich nicht verschwinden, Elise. Nicht so. Ich halte die Regel, Wort für Wort.

sacrifice_closure_terms_line.text: Dann hör zu: kein Name ohne Zustimmung, kein Zugriff ohne mein Ja, und beim ersten Bruch greift das Rückfall-Siegel. Ich bleibe - aber nicht rechtlos.

sacrifice_closure_creature_ack.text: ICH HÖRE DEINE GRENZEN. ICH HÖRE DEIN BLEIBEN. KEIN SCHWEIGEN MEHR.

plan_decision.text: Konrad... I'm sorry. But I have a plan. Trust me.

konrad_plan_react.text: Then do it. Quickly. Before HE takes over again.

seal_ritual_begin.text: The seal. Grandmother's way. I open the journal, find the page with the chant. The words are old, in no language I know, but somehow I understand them.

elise_seal_begin.text: Grandmother, if you can hear me — help me. Show me the way.

narration_seal_creature.text: YOU WANT TO BIND ME? LIKE HER? ANOTHER THIRTY YEARS OF DARKNESS?

narration_seal_resist.text: Rage. Real rage. The chamber shakes, the spirals spin faster. The entity does not want to go back to sleep.

elise_seal_2.text: Not forever! Only until... until we find a better way. Please!

seal_chant_begin.text: I begin to sing. The words Hilde taught me flow from my mouth like water from a spring. Old. Clear. Powerful.

seal_anchor_callback.text: Voss' Warnung trifft mich mitten im Lärm: Hand auf den Stein. Einen geliebten Namen nennen. Ich presse die Finger in die kalte Spirale und flüstere: Konrad. Dann: Margarethe. Der Druck in meinem Kopf lässt nicht nach - aber er bekommt eine Richtung. Ich bleibe ich.

seal_chant_practiced.text: Die Übung bei Hilde trägt mich. Ich kenne die Atempausen, die Brüche, die alten Silben. Meine Stimme zittert - aber sie hält.

seal_chant_unpracticed.text: Ich taste mich durch die fremden Silben. Nicht sauber, nicht perfekt - aber entschlossen. Jeder Ton ist ein Risiko, jeder Ton ein Schritt näher zum Siegel.

hilde_saves_seal.text: I begin the ritual, but the words are missing. The chant — I don't know it completely. Panic rises.

hilde_ritual_1.text: Child, I am here. I will sing with you. My voice is old, but together — together it will be enough.

elise_hilde_sing.text: Together. As Grandmother would have wanted.

hilde_ritual_2.text: Hilde's voice rises beside mine, brittle but sure. She knows every word, every turn. The melody grows stronger, fills the chamber.

seal_fails.text: I begin the ritual, but the words are missing. The chant — I don't know it completely. The air vibrates, the entity reacts, but the seal will not close.

elise_seal_fail.text: No... no, I need more time, I—

narration_seal_fail_creature.text: YOUR WORDS ARE EMPTY. YOU DO NOT KNOW THE CHANT. HOW CAN YOU BIND WHAT YOU DO NOT UNDERSTAND?

voss_escape_narration.text: The ritual fails. The chamber shakes. But Voss is there — he knows every stone, every tunnel.

voss_escape_2.text: This way! There is a second exit that only the pastors know!

hilde_escape_narration.text: Das Ritual scheitert. Die Kammer bebt. Aber Hilde greift nach meiner Hand und beginnt zu singen — einen anderen Gesang, alt und rau, der die Luft beruhigt.

hilde_escape_dialogue.text: Dieser Gesang beruhigt, nicht bindet! Lauf, Kind, solange es zuhört!

hilde_escape_stay.text: Ich singe weiter. Geh. Deine Großmutter würde mir nie vergeben, wenn ich dich hier sterben lasse.

packed_cross_escape_protection.text: Meine Knie geben fast nach - bis sich das Kreuz in meine Handkante drückt, klein und hart und real. Kein Wunder, nur ein Halt. Gerade genug, um nicht stehenzubleiben. Ich finde den Tritt zur Treppe und reiße mich aus der Kammer.

courage_escape.text: The ritual fails. The chamber breaks apart. But something in me refuses to give up. The same stubbornness that brought me here.

narration_courage_escape_2.text: I run. Through rubble, through darkness, through the roaring of the entity. My legs carry me even though they should have given out long ago.

understand_begin.text: Understanding. Not fighting, not binding. Understanding. I am a folklorist. I study the unknown. It is time to put that into practice.

understand_hilde_payoff.text: Ich habe auf mein Bauchgefühl gehört und zuerst Hilde aufgesucht. Nicht die Steine, sondern eine Stimme hat mir gezeigt, wie man zuhört.

understand_church_payoff.text: Ich bin zuerst in die Kirche gegangen. Zu den Zeichen im Stein. Vielleicht beginnt echtes Verstehen genau dort: am Ort, an dem die Angst Form annimmt.

elise_understand_1.text: I want to understand you. Not bind you, not destroy you. Show me what you are. Show me everything.

narration_understand_creature.text: UNDERSTAND? SIX HUNDRED YEARS AND NOBODY WANTED THAT. ARE YOU READY FOR WHAT YOU WILL SEE?

elise_understand_2.text: No. But I am asking anyway.

understand_ready.text: Grandmother's journal has prepared me. The symbols, the history, the connection. I understand enough to ask the right questions.

understand_unprepared.text: But I lack the knowledge. Grandmother's journal — I should have read it more thoroughly. Without preparation, the gaze into this abyss...

narration_understand_fail.text: YOU WANT TO SEE, BUT YOUR EYES ARE STILL CLOSED. PERHAPS I WILL OPEN THEM FOR YOU.

pact_begin.text: A pact. Negotiate. My name in the book gives me a voice. For the first time in six hundred years, someone will speak with the entity.

pact_hilde_payoff.text: Ich höre Hildes Stimme in mir: Ein Gegenüber ist kein Opfer. Wer verhandelt, hält die Grenze UND die Beziehung. Genau so trete ich dir jetzt entgegen.

pact_church_payoff.text: Ich sehe wieder die Spiralen im Stein unter dem Altar. Damals habe ich gelernt, dass Angst einen Ort hat - und dass man sie benennen kann. Genau deshalb kann ich heute Bedingungen stellen.

pact_confronted_voss_payoff.text: Ich habe Voss zur Wahrheit gezwungen, obwohl sie uns beide verletzt hat. Das hier folgt derselben Regel: Kein Pakt ohne Wahrheit, keine Grenze ohne Verantwortung.

pact_lied_to_voss_payoff.text: Und ich denke an die Lüge in der Kirche. Angst hat mich damals eng gemacht. Nicht wieder. Wer ein uraltes Wesen an Bedingungen binden will, muss selbst ohne Täuschung sprechen.

questioned_letter_pact_payoff.text: Schon bei Georg am ersten Abend habe ich nach dem Brief gefragt statt nur zu nicken. Genau dort hat es begonnen: Erst fragen, dann glauben. Diese Regel gilt auch hier unten.

questioned_candle_pact_payoff.text: Und ich erinnere mich an seine Kerze - an den Moment, in dem ich gelernt habe, dass selbst Schutz ein Preisetikett tragen kann. Ein Pakt ohne klare Grenzen wäre nur ein neues Opfer mit schönerem Namen.

elise_pact_1.text: I propose a deal. No more sacrifices. Never again. In return, we offer what was never offered in six hundred years: chosen presence, explicit consent, and no death.

narration_pact_creature.text: HUMANS BREAK PROMISES. WHY SHOULD I BELIEVE YOU?

elise_pact_2.text: My grandmother kept her promise for thirty years—month after month, chant after chant. Tell me one time she lied to you.

narration_pact_creature_2.text: Silence. Long, infinite contemplation. Then: NO. SHE WAS... DIFFERENT. LIKE YOU.

destroy_begin.text: Enough talk. Enough pity. This thing has accepted six hundred years of human sacrifices. Regardless of what it feels — it must end.

elise_destroy_1.text: Enough. Six hundred years of blood. Six hundred years of fear. Today you die!

narration_destroy_creature.text: YOU WANT TO KILL ME? ME? I AM OLDER THAN YOUR DUST. YOU CANNOT TEAR DOWN A MOUNTAIN WITH BARE HANDS.

destroy_attempt.text: I attack. With everything I have — will, rage, desperation. Grandmother's amulet glows, the herbs flare up, and I hurl everything against the consciousness beneath the stone.

destroy_attempt_3.text: My attack bounces off like a wave against a continent. The entity is not evil — it is VAST. And the impact... the impact wakes it.

narration_destroy_recoil.text: PAIN. YOU GIVE ME PAIN. I HAVE HAD ENOUGH PAIN.

elise_destroy_2.text: It... it is moving. Oh God, it is MOVING—

route_fallback.text: I stand before the entity without a plan, without preparation. Just me and the abyss. And the abyss stares back.

narration_fallback_creature.text: YOU HAVE CHOSEN NO PATH. THEN I CHOOSE FOR YOU.

narration_3_no_key.text: Die letzte Tür zur Kammer steht offen. Irgendjemand hat sie rechtzeitig geöffnet. Hildes Kräuter brennen in einer Schale neben mir, ihr Rauch steigt spiralförmig auf. Großmutters Journal liegt aufgeschlagen.

read_final_entries_memory.text: Ich denke an die letzte Seite: "Manche Wege entstehen erst im Moment." Kein Befehl, nur Verantwortung. Genau dafür stehe ich jetzt hier.

seal_tradition_memory.text: Die Gespräche mit Voss und Konrad schneiden durch meine Panik: Tradition ohne Mitgefühl wurde zur Fütterung. Ich wiederhole den Gesang anders - als Grenze, nicht als Opferbefehl.

stayed_in_village_ritual_memory.text: Ich sehe die Entscheidung wieder vor mir: bleiben oder wegrennen. Damals habe ich den härteren Weg gewählt. Heute ist derselbe Weg nur tiefer geworden.

tried_to_flee_ritual_memory.text: Ich war schon einmal auf der Flucht, im Kreis durch denselben Wald. Der Unterschied ist: Heute renne ich nicht mehr vor etwas weg. Heute gehe ich auf etwas zu.

otto_pressure_defied_payoff.text: Ich sehe Otto vor mir, wie er im Hof stand und drohte, das Dorf zu holen. Ich habe ihm widersprochen - und genau deshalb zittert meine Stimme jetzt nicht. Diese Nacht gehört nicht seiner Panik.

otto_pressure_complied_payoff.text: Ottos Ultimatum hängt mir noch im Nacken: erster Glockenschlag, keine Verzögerung. Ich habe ihm zugesagt, um Zeit zu gewinnen - jetzt muss ich liefern, bevor seine Angst oben in der Kirche zur Meute wird.

konrad_watch_ritual_memory.text: Zwischen zwei Glockenschlägen höre ich oben drei dumpfe Schläge Metall auf Holz - Georgs Antwort auf unser Sicherungszeichen vom Schulhaus. Kein Entwarnen. Nur das Versprechen, dass Konrad nicht unbeobachtet zwischen Otto und das Wesen gerät.

ritual_breath_count_payoff.text: Annas Vier-Atemzüge-Takt sitzt noch: ein, zwei, drei, vier - erst dann spreche ich. Das nimmt dem Summen den Taktvorteil und hält meine Stimme bei mir.

extra_support_bundle_ritual_payoff.text: Das Bündel von letzter Nacht liegt geöffnet neben der Schale. Der Metallkeil hält das Journal auf der richtigen Seite, der Kräuterfaden nimmt dem süßen Geruch die Spitze, und Voss' Glockenzeiten geben meinem Atem einen Takt. Kein Wundermittel. Aber genug, um aus Angst wieder Methode zu machen.

schoolhouse_echo_georg.text: Aus Richtung Schule schlägt einmal eine Glocke gegen Metall - zu früh, zu schief für den Kirchturm. Dann zweimal kurz Holz auf Holz. Georgs Code. Keine Entwarnung, nur ein Lagebild: Konrad bewegt sich, aber er bleibt im Korridor zwischen Tür und Tafel.

schoolhouse_echo_ward.text: Durch das Mauerwerk dringt ein trockenes Kreidekratzen bis in die Kammer. Dann ein dumpfer Ton, als würde jemand gegen den Türrahmen stoßen - genau dort, wo ich die drei gebrochenen Spiralen gezogen habe. Der Laut reißt ab. Der Kreis hält. Für jetzt.

schoolhouse_echo_distance.text: Ein falscher Glockenschlag aus Richtung Schulhaus frisst sich in meinen Nacken - derselbe Köder wie im Wald: Komm zurück, sieh nach, verliere den Takt. Ich presse die Finger tiefer in den Stein und zähle meine Atemzüge statt Schritte. Wenn ich jetzt abbiege, stirbt der Plan vor der ersten Zeile.

schoolhouse_echo_resolve.text: Nicht jetzt. Konrad, halt durch. Ich hole dich da raus - aber nur, wenn ich ES zuerst binde.

approach_commitment_seal_payoff.text: Der Kreidering aus der Nacht erscheint vor meinem inneren Auge: "Bleiben". Nicht am Ritual kleben um jeden Preis - am Ziel. Dreißig Jahre Zeit kaufen, ohne die Lüge weiterzureichen.

approach_commitment_understand_payoff.text: Unter meinen drei Fragen höre ich den vierten Satz mit: Wenn ich nur noch staune, frage ich weiter. Genau das hält mich im Gespräch, als das Summen nach Ehrfurcht schmeckt.

approach_commitment_destroy_payoff.text: Ich sehe den eingeklemmten Keil an der Türfuge vor mir. Das ist der Deal mit mir selbst: Wenn der Boden bricht, zählt nicht Stolz, nur Exit und Konsequenz.

approach_commitment_pact_payoff.text: Im Journal steckt das gefaltete Klauselblatt auf Großmutters letzter Seite. Das erinnert mich: verhandeln heißt weder kuschen noch vernichten, sondern Grenzen so klar sprechen, dass auch Angst sie nicht verschiebt.

schoolhouse_command_intro.text: Der Drang, zur Schule hochzurennen, sitzt mir wie ein Haken unter dem Brustbein. Ich kann den Plan jetzt nur halten, wenn ich meine Sorge in einen klaren Befehl verwandle.

choices: Über Georgs Klopfcode den Haltebefehl senden: Konrad sichern, Tür geschlossen lassen, bis der zweite Kehrvers steht.
Kein Zusatzbefehl - Atem zählen, Kreidekreis halten, dem Köder keinen Zentimeter geben.

schoolhouse_command_hold.text: Drei kurz, eins lang, drei kurz. Georg versteht: halten, nicht jagen. Wenn Konrad heute bricht, dann hinter einer verriegelten Tür - nicht im Ritualkreis.

schoolhouse_command_tempo.text: Ich sende nichts. Jeder Zusatzton wäre ein Riss im Takt. Also nur Atem, Stein, Kehrvers - und der Entschluss, Konrad später zu retten, nicht jetzt.

schoolhouse_command_commit.text: Die Entscheidung tut weh, aber sie schließt die innere Fluchtluke. Von hier an gibt es nur noch vorwärts: binden, dann bergen.

schoolhouse_command_choice_hold_payoff.text: Unten bleibt mein Takt sauber, oben hält Georg die Linie. Der Befehl kostet Vertrauen - aber er verhindert, dass Sorge zur Panik wird.

schoolhouse_command_choice_tempo_payoff.text: Ich tue nichts außer zählen, und genau das stabilisiert den Kreis. Kein Heldensprung, kein Umweg - nur Disziplin, die uns beide am Leben hält.

promised_konrad_after_ritual_ritual_payo.text: Der alte Schwur aus der Nacht am Schulhaus sitzt noch immer fest: erst binden, dann Konrad holen. Genau dieser Satz hält meine Hände ruhig, als das Summen mir eine Abkürzung ins Gewissen flüstert.

voss_anchor_margarethe_ritual.text: Mitten im Druck fällt mir mein fester Satz aus der Kirche wieder ein: Hand auf den Stein, Margarethes Name, dann erst sprechen. "Margarethe." Die Stimmen werden nicht leiser - aber sie verlieren den Griff auf mein Gesicht.

voss_anchor_anna_ritual.text: Der Lärm will mich aus dem Takt reißen. Ich drücke die Finger tiefer in die Spirale und halte mich an den Namen, den ich vorher gewählt habe: "Anna." Die Angst bleibt, aber sie richtet sich wieder nach vorn statt nach oben.

voss_anchor_georg_ritual.text: Ich höre das Summen und denke an den Namen, den ich nicht improvisieren musste: "Georg." Der Gedanke an seine ruhige Linie oben zwingt meine Stimme unten in denselben Takt.

georg_watch_school_ritual_payoff.text: Dass wir gestern schon ein stilles Sicherungszeichen fürs Schulhaus gelegt haben, nimmt der Entscheidung heute die Schärfe. Kein Improvisieren mehr - nur den vorbereiteten Kanal nutzen oder bewusst schließen.

narration_3_journal.text: Georg's key opened the last door. Hilde's herbs burn in a bowl beside me, their smoke rising in spirals. Grandmother's journal lies open.

narration_4_journal.text: Grandmother's letter in my breast pocket. Hilde's amulet around my neck. Everything that connects me to the living.

narration_3_nojournal.text: Georg's key opened the last door. Hilde's herbs burn in a bowl beside me, their smoke rising in spirals.
